1.content:
As with anything owned by Wondertainment, the cheery facade masks a dark underbelly. The staff, by necessity, have been organized into a strict hierarchy; with management at the top; technicians, writers, and actors a rung lower on the ladder; and sanitation, maintenance, and grunt workers at the bottom.

Actors are the most sought-after positions; for both the prestige of such a position and the benefits afterward. Contracts are set for five years at the minimum, and anyone who makes it through that crucible can get any Wondertainment-owned role they desire. The selection and training process is rigorous too, a strict regimen of lessons to teach them how to stay in-character no matter their form or situation.

Many a proud graduate of that program have been bitterly disappointed by the nature of their assignment. Gender, age, height: all these and more are no barrier to the Wondrous™ auto-surgeons of Meconstruction!

Writers are assigned to create exciting new Plotlines for their awaiting guests. There are a few that create Wonderful™ experiences every time they put pen to paper, but a fair amount of the writer’s room is burnt out, and just rehash usual tropes for their none-the-wiser guests. A few luminaries are employed as coaches for the actors, watching plots unfold through contact-lens cameras whilst whispering plot twists and story directions into the actor’s cleverly hidden earpieces. Whether the actors listen or not is a bit of a toss-up.

Technicians are stretched to their creative limit as well by Wondertainment’s nigh-unmeetable quota: designing new animatronics for creatures and roles unoccupiable by humans; new gadgets and special effects to enhance the realism of each environment; and pushing the envelope of Meconstruction’s technology.

(There are rumblings of discontent among the actors about artificially intelligent robots created to take their starring roles in the park, but those are mostly dismissed with much rolling of the eyes and scoffs of ‘Science fiction!’)

Wonder-World’s mantra is ‘customer-obsession’, after all. Who needs to follow labor laws when you have mountains of cash?

That being said, who are you?

111.content:
No matter what beliefs you hold towards the kind of towering figures created by late-stage capitalism; or the piddly, outdated tomes that contain ‘consumer-and-labor-protection-laws’, one has to admit that WonderWorld — the pinnacle achievement of Walter Wonder — is quite impressive.

Or a monstrosity, if you‘re one of those bleeding hearts.

Walter, or Dr. Wonder, pondered these comments at the plate glass window of his eleventh coastal home, swirling a glass of brandy that was more expensive than some apartments in his hand.

Could it all be true? Could he be some sort of affluenza-afflicted monster, playing god with the unwashed masses?

No, he concluded. It was his critics who were wrong.

With this in mind, he enlisted his (ostensibly) loyal manservant, Chauncey to man a Meconstructive booth and sculpt his middle-aged form into an unrecognizable form, one that could hide a microscopic camera with ease, to capture footage that proved that things weren’t that bad, to prove that all was truly, Wonderful™.

(The out-of-touch coot hadn’t heard of Undercover Boss.)

What did the billionaire go undercover as?

121.content:
Here are a few of the many roles you may find yourself playing in the sleek metropolis of Wonder-City:

Captain Capable; the archetypical ‘flying brick’ with a cornucopia of other Plotline-convenient superpowers and one of the founding members of the ‘Utopian Alliance’, he’s a bit of a boyscout: humble in his accomplishments but steadfast in the face of the evil. His civilian identity is Chet Tompkins, a mild-mannered insurance salesman.

The actors that are chosen to play him usually aren’t nearly as humble or kind, however. It’s one of the most sought-after positions for many a reason: the well-muscled athletic physique, the uncountable female Guests hanging off their arms, and the center-stage focus in many a storyline.

Of course, all this means that the actors for the Captain are easily shunted off to other roles, what with all the eager mummers in queue behind them…

Mighty Maid; She’s also a founding member of the Utopian Alliance, though you’d never guess it. In her civilian identity, she goes by the name Margot Marseille, a young thing who has earned the dubious honor of the cities’ top maid with inconspicuous use of her ‘super-cleaning’ powers. With an auburn bob topped by a ruffled headband, a ridiculous French accent, a nigh-physically-impossible hourglass-figure, and a penchant for getting caught in the most basic of traps, her detractors claim that she sets feminism and the reputation of a certain Western European country back fifty years.

Wonder-Land, of course, dismissed these opinions outright. Hundreds of trust-fund teens and lecherous old men paid out the nose for a chance to ogle the ‘Servant of the People,’ with the Writers and Technicians eagerly obliging: the former managing to get a checkbox for ‘Mighty Maid romance,’ on the Wonder-City guest application, and the latter designing intentional flaws into her corset for more wardrobe malfunctions.

In fact, Mighty Maid was the focal point of one of the company’s few legal losses : the sight of a sniffling young thing tearfully telling tales about mincing around for the hungry eyes of the elite was a bit too much for the public and courts to stomach.

The financial loss was relatively minor, in the scope of all things, but Wondertainment vowed to never let it happen again. So now, if you carefully watch the graduation ceremony of the Actor Training Program, you can see one or two young men goggling at the contents of their enveloped assignment. If you choose to follow them to the auto-surgeon, you can watch them wobble out of their appointment looking markedly different; a good amount of their former mass flushed down the medical waste chute, save for a specially preserved piece. Even if they talk after their contracts are up, who would believe them?

Only the actor, direct coworkers, and management are privy to this secret, the former two threatened with immediate severance without pay nor form reinstitution if they disclose the secret to any guest or refuse to play their part. Despite this, you can find quite the number of red-tressed doppelgangers in nearby cities. To this date, no one outside of Wondertainment has quite connected the dots.

Black Sable; real name: Carmilla Yahontov, a rich heiress who moonlights as a super-villain, pilfering the contents of vaults with usage of her super-intangibility (Which is realized in the park by cleverly hidden secret passages.)

Though many female actor aspirants try to snag the role of the Sterling Scoundrel with the hope of being the full-fledged badass she is on the silver screen, most are disappointed by the steady stream of moneyed masochists who come to be degraded by the near-amazon.

Some are fine with it, of course.

Who shall you be playing the part of, then?

1212.title: Mighty Maid

12121.content:
The day was finally here - graduation! The Town Hall of Wonder City, normally the site of dazzling, effects-laden battles between the forces of good-actors and evil-actors, has today been fitted out with several hundred cheap plastic chairs to accommodate the forty gowned graduates of the Wondertainment Actor Training Program and their friends and families.

And there you are, front-row seat. Being here, in the vaulted halls right at the heart of the WonderWorld complex, you can't help but feel excited and trepidation in equal measure. How many thousands of actors have given their utmost to amaze the audience, to bring a touch of magic into a mundane world. How many millions of excited visitors, men and children alike, have passed through here and watched in wonder, believing for just a moment that dreams really can come true?

The weight of that obligation presses down from you, made all the more real by the stern, granite visage of Doctor Wonder staring down from the stone statue of 'Mayor Wonder, Established Wonder City in 1837' at the front of the hall.

Nervously you fiddle with the hem of the rental graduation robe. Your fiance notices and slides her hand within yours, interlacing her fingers to stop you fidgeting, and gives you kiss on the cheek. "You're going to do great. We're all excited to see who you're going to be," she says warmly.

"Speak for yourself, I'm just here for the base package," your dad jokes, slapping you on the back so hard that it dislodges your mortarboard hat. "Three days in WonderWorld almost makes up for the three years of tuition we paid."

"I promised I'll pay that back." By which you mean, 5 years on your contract and Wondertainment will void the debt. Nobody pays off loans of that magnitude on an actor's salary.

Up on the podium, Mayor Hamilton Hayworth Hill III - or at least the actor now known as such - glances at his watch in impatience. The Town Hall is set aside for this occasion for one hour every year, and one hour only. In 27 minutes 14 seconds, the villain known as Firefly is due to burst through the front doors and the pyrotechnics under the floor will go off, with or without a roomful of graduates sat on top of them. Where the hell is Captain Capable?!

"Sorry for the delay, ladies and gentlemen! Had to stop a bank robbery on the way here, you know how it is!" comes the valiant call across the room.

The lighting technician is at least partially on the ball. The lights dim. A spotlight swinging up to one the empty balconies of the auditorium, drawing the audience's gaze. The spotlight quickly shifts a different balcony where stands Captain Capable, his bleached white smile shining brilliantly. Striking a noble pose, he rises into the air and floats over the crowd.

"More like Captain Cable, I can see the wires," Maria whispers in your ear. You hush her, not wanting to ruin the magic for the rest. The audience watches transfixed as the Captain makes his landing beside the podium and extends his red-white-and-blue gloved hand to shake the hands of the scowling mayor. There is a brief pause as a stage hand dressed as the sidekick Boy Competent rushes on stage to release the harness on the Captain's back.

"You're gonna make such a better Captain than that guy," says Maria, looking at you with admiration.

"In my dreams am I going to get that lucky," you reply, showing her your crossed fingers.

"Ladies and Gentlemen gathered here today..." begins the Captain, glancing at the clock. "... let's begin."

One by one, the graduates' names are read out. They go up on stage to shake the Captain's hand, receive their diploma, an envelope containing the details of the role they will be playing, and most importantly, a few private words of wisdom from the Big C himself. Then it's your turn.

Wow, your hands are sweaty. Thank god the Captain is wearing gloves. With every eye and a swelteringly hot floodlight on you, it feels to take an age just walking to the stage. Somehow it is challenge just to move one foot after the other without tripping over the steps or themselves. How have three years of stage school not prepared you better for this moment? Your heart feels like it is beating out of your chest...

... and then it stops as a cry of "we love you, Charlie!" comes from your fiance. The crowd titters at the sudden outburst, and the Captain himself puts his head back and gives a theatrical guffaw.

The leather of the Captain's glove is worn smooth from hundreds of hands as it shakes yours. He hands you your diploma and the envelope, though his head is turned away, fixated on somebody in the front row. "Quite a mouth your girlfriend's get on her," the Captain mutters below the threshold of the microphone.

"Uh, yeah, she's got a pair of lungs on her alright", you laugh in embarrassment.

The Captain leans in, your heart leaping in anticipation of his words of encouragement. "Oh, she's certainly got a sweet pair of something," he sneers, slapping your shoulder and guiding you with a shove towards the far side of the stage.

The far side of the stage is dark and quiet, the sounds of the auditorium soon swallowed up by the thick red velvet curtains. A set of stairs leads down and down. As you descend, the gilded, baroque architecture of the Town Hall very quickly becomes grey concrete and stark fluorescent lighting. Yet this mundane, industrial area thrills you. This is the actual WonderWorld utility network! The Wonder Kingdom is fabled to have the largest utilidor system in the world, a network of tunnels running under the park to allow its actors to get from place to place out of sight of the visitors. This is where the magic is made!

You take a deep lungful, savouring the moment. Oddly, it doesn't smell much like magic. It smells like rust and sweat. And there is the strange, strong scent of hot fat and burnt hair which only grows stronger as you progress further down the corridor.

There is nobody here to greet you, and it is eerily deserted even of actors. There is just a misspelled sign - 'gradautes this way' - pointing down half a mile of industrial corridor before there is another sign - 'garduates check number'. Beyond, the corridor is lined on both sides with numbered doorways.

The stench of cooking flesh and burnt hair is overpowering here, and there is an odd, muffled noise just at the edge of hearing, a repetitive thud echoing through the concrete like somebody hammering against a wall.

In the moment of confusion, you look to the envelope for guidance. Printed on the front in glitter is the number '7'. You step through door 7, tearing open the envelope as you go.

The room beyond is little larger than a closet with a bare bulb illuminating side walls of steel, a floor-to-ceiling mirror in front of you, and a concrete floor crisscrossed with drainage channels and a wide drain. The door seals shut behind with a heavy, pneumatic clunk.
12121.title: Freshly graduated from the Actor Training Program

121211.content:
You move to try the door handle only to find that there is none. The door has completely sealed shut, becoming just another steel wall of the phone booth-sized chamber.

The smell of burnt meat and chemicals is enough to make you gag. The bare bulb above flickers and hums. You notice a blue residue encrusted to the sides of the bulb in streaks, as if some liquid has poured down it and dripped. Above the bulb, nozzles are set in to the ceiling, encrusted with the blue chemical too.

"Um, he-hello?" you ask.

The sound echoed back at you from the walls, the only company the image of yourself reflected back upon the mirror wall, looking rather absurd in their ornate, billowing graduation gown. Your face looks pale and nervous. Why should you be afraid? You're only a dozen feet beneath the streets of Wonder City, the happiest theme park in the world. Nothing bad happens here.

Yet your fingers betray your nerves, absently tugging at tearing at the heavy parchment of the envelope, tearing it into strips and the strips into confetti to distract your mind. You'd forgotten all about the letter! It is sure to explain everything!

Dear Charles Wright,

Congratulations on successfully passing the Wondrous™ Certified Actors Training Program and Thank You for agreeing to become a part of WonderWorld: The Theme Park of the Future, Today!

In order to keep the magic of WonderWorld a secret, we would like to remind you that you continue to be held under the Non-Disclosure Agreement signed at your admission to the Program and that any breach of said agreement with regards to the workings of WonderWorld or any activities you may perform, or have performed upon you, to visitors, social media, traditional media, law enforcement, or government agencies will be punished to the full extent of the law. Furthermore, Wondertainment maintains the right to terminate your contract immediately due to this or any other infraction, with any outstanding tuition fees waived by Wondertainment for the 5-year probation period required to be repaid with 14-days.

And furthermore... Welcome!

During your years at WonderCollege, you may have been studying with us but what you may not know is that we have been studying you! Using personality surveys conducted discretely during your three years with us, as well as assessments submitted by your tutors and classmates, we have hand selected for you the perfect role within our extensive stable of characters, which we believe is well within your acting range. Don't disappoint us!

Please find below the list of what we believe are your greatest strengths as an actor, which were used in our selection process:
- Pep 67%
- Naivete 96%
- Height 170cm [within acceptable adjustable parameters]
- Servility 36% [within acceptable adjustable parameters]
- Litigitinousness 12%

Considering this, furthering your required Meconstruction, you have been cast in the role of...!

The bottom third of the letter has been folded over and glued down. A handful of gold glitter pours out when you open it up.

Mighty Maid

"Wait, what." This is a mistake, right? No. Your name is right there at the top of the letter.

Mighty Maid is a joke of a character, a sexist relic of a time in the 1970s when comic books were written by misogynists and illustrated to pander to the 13-18 male demographic, after they discovered that a big breasted French maid on the front page tripled sales. Her creator, William Byrne, had been infamous for his love of bondage, and so her stories usually involved her being tied up after (once again) naively accepting the job of cleaning the evil villain's volcano lair, and typically ended with her being rescued by Captain Capable and spanked over his knee on the steps of the town hall.

It was frankly baffling to you that company as progressive as Wondertainment had deigned her appropriate for a role in their Wonder Cinematic Universe, let alone their theme park. Fortunately they had chosen to improve the poor actress' working conditions after that disgruntled employee had come forward.

"Hello?" you say again to the cubicle. "I think there's been a mistake."

To your surprise, with a tiny electronic click, the mirror in front of you suddenly becomes a window. A window on to a broad, darkened room illuminated by the thousands of glowing switches on banks of computer terminals, and the light that streams from your cubicle and the cubicles either side of you. Though you cannot see into the cubicles next to you, you can see the light from them playing over the faces of the men in white coats seated at the computers - some of the light is blue and ripples, as if shining though a spray of chemicals pouring down the window; another distinctly shows the shadows of arms thrashing before the bulb.

The man at the console situated in front of your cubicle leans towards a microphone at his desk. "No mistake."

*click* The window becomes a mirror once more.

"What! I'm not Mighty Maid!"

*click* The mirror becomes a window. "Not yet." *click*

A cold sense of dread is starting to form in the pit of your stomach. You bang your fist on the mirror. "Mighty Maid's a girl!!"

*click* "Do not bang on the glass." *click*

You can picture her clearly from the news coverage - the video recordings taken by visitors of her mincing about the tropical resort on stilettos with a frilly black skirt hitched up over her backside, bending over with her feather duster to clean up every piece of trash the gaggle of leering male fans threw in front of her. You picture the middle-age men pinching the curvy cheeks of the 2D character they'd grown up fantasizing over. You slam your fist harder.

*click* "I said don't touch the glass," says the voice icily. The man reaches for a blue dial on his desk, cranking it up. There is a gurgle above...

Psccchhhhh. A mist of neon blue liquid sprays from the ceiling. In a moment, you look as if you've fallen into a port-a-potty as the acrid stuff drips down your torso, soaks through your clothes, until you're sodden to the skin. You splutter in protest. The man cranks the dial further and the mist becomes like a heavy rain.

There is something thicker dripping down the back of your neck. You reach your hands up to your head and pull them away covered in black goop. The mortarboard hat was... melting.

"Hey, that was a rental!"

The letter, envelope, and diploma in your hands are becoming mush, the thick parchment like a rice paper that tears apart and dribbles through your fingers. You can feel the deep groves of the drainage channels beneath your feet, as the thick rubber soals of your shoes begins to melt and wash away. The heavy graduation gown slings to you, chunks of it bubbling and sloughing away.

The treacle-like melted plastic and fabric of the mortarboard dribbles still down your scalp. You try to pull more of it out of your hair. Your fingers comes away matted in a handful of your auburn curls.
121211.title: Reading the letter

choices: Manacles pinion your limbs to the wall, with one even covering your mouth! Rude.
He calls over a writer while the process continues.
He ignores you while the process continues.
1212113.content:
You stare at the clump of matted hair in your hands, the blue sodden thing closely resembling a wet, mutant gerbil. Dots connect in your head with lightning-fast speed, and Mighty Maid’s scenes in the latest WCU films play in your head:

A two-minute-long costume change scene with plenty of low and high angle shots that bumped the rating up to PG-13.

Cooing ‘Oui’ in response to Captain Capable’s inspirational speech and nodding so furiously that her bustier nearly slipped off.

Raising her feather duster in victory after barely contributing to the fight against Mal’Traxxas, the Planet Eater.

God, did she have a single sentence?!

A good amount of body hair sloughs off with an unpleasant tingle as the sense of dread in your stomach blossoms into indignation. With a self-righteous fist, you rap on the glass.

“Excuse me?! Hello?”

The faint silhouette of the man clicks back onto the mirror, and the best adjective that could apply would be ‘haggard’. Your lip involuntarily curls, but you push it down. They needed to know the massive mistake they were making.

“Sir, please don’t knock on the glass.” He turns the blue dial once again and the blue rain above you becomes a monsoon. He kneads the bridge of his nose as you splutter through the chemicals. “And please hold still, this is —”

An indignant bristling claws its way to the surface. “I most certainly will not hold still! I played the lead role for a six-month-run of the Scottish Play, and you’re relegating me to a bit part?”

The man looks bemused, but quickly wipes the expression off his face and fiddles with the console. The downpour of chemicals stops, and two jointed mechanical arms extend out of the ceiling, a rubber edged blade between the two of them. “Sir, I think you’ll find the battery of papers you signed waives any right to choice of form…”

The rubber descends to the back of your skull, and scrapes downwards, catching any remaining bits of pesky keratin. “Well, I want to talk to your manager!”

You cross your arms somewhat defiantly and glower at the pane of glass, which doesn’t come across that well, what with the lack of eyebrows and all. The rubber blade now squeegeeing your front doesn’t help much either.

“You’re cooking a side of wagyu beef well done,” you add. “It’s a waste.

Bemused, the artless heathen taps a few buttons on his console and…
1212113.title: Resign yourself to the process

choices: A second wind re-energizes you! (Not that it matters.)
A different-coloured chemical starts to spurt down.
Mechanical implements extend from hidden compartments.
1212114.content:
Both of your hands shoot to your head to protect your locks — you’d spent thirty bucks on the coif, after all — but it’s a fruitless task. The blue gush dislodges loose strands with pressure alone and soon enough your vision is clogged with glossy clumps of blue. The constant downpour on your bare scalp is a strange feeling, but the fact that all your clothes — including your lucky boxers — have been washed down the drain is a bit more attention-grabbing.

You cover your shame for a second, but the glass has switched back to the mirror. You move your gaze to your mechanical foe: the nozzle. Distressingly, the hand you use to protect your eyes from the deluge of blue is alabaster-pale. Even the burn scar you got as a kid has faded away, indiscernible from the rest of your arm.

You watch your arm hair get blasted off with the rivulets of pen-ink liquid, watching the little threads dance around the floor before sluicing down the drain. This has to stop. You take a deep breath and squat, tensing the muscles in your legs. You cast a baleful gaze at your quarry; it’s only two-or-so feet above your head. You can do this.

The glass changes with a click. The white-coated man leans closer to his microphone. “Please do not disrupt any appliances in the Meconstruction Chamber.”

“Fuck you.” you growl. The curse is strange and satisfying on your tongue: WonderCollege program discouraged the usage of harsh language, with grade-letter-reduction as punishment past the initial three strikes. You haven’t said anything harsher than ‘heck’ in three years, but the moment couldn’t be more appropriate.

With a grunt of effort, you leap into the air, clawing your fingers through the torrent of blue, before your fingers find glorious purchase on the metal nub.

A triumphant laugh peels out of your mouth! For about three seconds, because the resulting jolt coursing through you is enough to completely spasm every striated muscle. You feel the dull sensation of your body impacting the floor and of your limbs uselessly thumping against the wall.

It takes you around twenty seconds for you to fully recover. Twenty seconds of blue stuff lashing down on your face, wiping any trace of follicular growth from you face, even that light stubble you were working so hard on.

With a click, the mirror changes back to a window. “Told you so.” the man intones, voice bereft of amusement.

You swipe the back of a hand across your lashless lids to clear the final bit of hat-goop and turn your bared orbs to the now-mirror.

“What the hell was that?!” you hiss, pointing a finger up at the nozzles.
click. “Anti-tamper mechanism.” A little pause, then another click. “Foul language is against our Wonderful Code of Conduct, please refrain from using it in whilst in our employ. Best to break bad habits early.” click

The anger coursing through you mixes with dread and forms a foul cocktail of what might resemble determination. There’s only one thing left to do: You struggle to your feet, fumbling a hand along the wall for support. The soreness has just start to hit. “I quit, then!” you choke out. The words almost hurt as they leave your lips. Your dreams feel like they’re dissolving before you, much like everything else you brought into the chamber.

*click* The man appears in front of you once again, but his till-now-impassive expression has a quizzical bent to it. He beckons over a neighboring man and the two confer behind their hands, before the second shrugs and walks away.

Your tormentor massages the bridge of his nose, before pressing the microphone button with another click.

“Alright then. Tuition’ll have to be recouped within the stipulated 14-day period.”

You gulp down the weight in your throat and along with a bit of blue liquid and nod. “Okay.”

“And…” He types unidentifiable sums into a nearby calculator. “... around forty percent of the estimated income’ll have to be paid. That’s forty-thousand credits at least”

“Wait, what?”

“And the wasted Meconstructive process; that’s gonna hike those numbers. We’ve already used ‘round half of the Defoliating ”

Your face blanches. “This isn’t going to stop!?”

The man blinks owlishly. “Of course not. That would be horribly unsafe.” A few more numbers are inputted. “And the Wonder-brand camisole and miniskirt’ll be a forty. Ah, do you want underwear with that?”

“I can’t— I d-don’t—”

“Well, our Mighty Maid frilled-bras are around fifteen credits, and they support and display. I’ll put you down for it, and if you have any complaints afterward, you can return it for 15% of the price in-store credit.”

You slide down along the slick wall, only half paying attention to the flood coursing around you. “If I can’t pay this back, what’ll…”

“Liquidation of your assets, garnished wages, and the same for direct relations,” he sniffs. “Does anyone read these contracts?”

A part of you wants to melt along with the rest of your clothes and wash away into the sewers. This wasn’t wonderful at all. You cough out a bit of liquid and try to find your voice. “Um, I-i’d like to rescind my… hasty decision, from, uh, a few seconds ago.”

The voice stifles a cough-snor. “Welcome back.”

The drainage channels are an uncomfortable bed, but you don’t really have the energy to care. Blue liquid cascades on your face as an “Oh god…” escapes your lips.

click “That’ll have to be ‘Mon dieu.”

Goddammit.
1212114.title: Something else

choices: A torrent of viscous neon pink goo begins to pour from on high
A numbing white foam fills the entire chamber
An inky black ointment is sprayed on your scalp
12121142.content:
Ever square inch of your skin tingles weirdly, as the blue liquid continues to pour down the defoliated surface. You run your hands over your chest, feeling the last of the baby fuzz come away under the touch, adhering to your fingers in clumps for a moment before it too is rinsed away. The flesh feels smooth as rubber beneath.

*click* "Sir, we're going to need you to stand up." *click*

The tone brooks no argument. On shaky legs, you rise, facing the mirror.

*click* "Yeah, if you can just turn around now... that's great. And, uh, if you can just bend forwards just a little."

"What?!"

"Bend. Forwards. This is quality control. We need to check that we get everywhere. How would it look for the park if we allowed a Mighty Maid to go on show with a hairy crack where her showstopper should be? This is going to be on thousands on instagrams and facebook posts, alright, so bend over." *click*

Just think of the money. Think of Maria, of the ring you'll buy her, of the home for the two of you that you'll be able to afford with this job...

You bite your tongue and place your hands on the wall that had once been a door, leaning forward at the waist. The cobalt coloured liquid poured down your asscrack.

*click* "That's greeeat. Now if you can just spread those cheeks..."

Think of the house you'll buy. Picture the picket fence, the winding garden path that leads to the door. Picture the master bedroom for you and Maria, the creche for the baby...

Slowly, begrudingly, you move your hands around to your backside. Just pretend you're mooning him, you try to convince yourself, as you pull your ass cheeks apart.

"Great. Hold there." The second technician is beckoned over again. The two men consult for a minute, each stepping up to the mirrored glass in turn, pressing their noses almost to the glass and inspecting you closely. You scowl back at them, though their attention is more focused on your ass than your face, and they pay you no mind. Your tormentor is unshaven, dark rims under his eyes and coffee stains about the lapel of his labcoat. He looks like a man at the tail end of an 18 hour shirt.

The fat is rinsed of gore, is sprayed down with chemicals, and then the vat is very gently, very carefully heated - not enough to kill the cells, but enough to soften the fibrous parts until it all liquefies, the flesh of hundreds of different animals flowing together.

Human adipose tissue is expensive, hard to come by, and tightly controlled, which means outside eyes prying into the resort's business. Animal fat is plentiful and even more effective for Meconstruction purposes due to fact that the human body struggles to utilise it, to burn it. A recipient could diet and exercise to the extreme, and the animal adipose would remain unchanged throughout it all even as the rest of the body grows thinner and ultimately starves. There have been people who've died of malnutrition while still sporting their generous Meconstruction endowments.

There was an additional benefit to sourcing the fat locally. 1212114213414211.content:
The grafting system was remarkable in its efficacy, though that could be said about many things in WonderWorld. Tendons, T-bones, and all other sorts of animal viscera would be sorted through carefully-yet-quickly by a machine eye, picking out the least cooked bits of leftover food to drape over the latest actor’s face.

Glitches in the past led unsupervised Meconstructive machines to staple xenografts-faces made of melting fat and cooked tendons over a poor sap’s face, creating a visage that looked horrifying but smelled rather good. The thought made Zach cringe a bit, but was the main reason why he had a job now, so gift horses and all that.

There were still a few things to work on. The subject had quite the chin, almost Captain Capable level — shame the position wouldn’t be open ‘till next year. For now, he had to shave the chin down to a more-feminine, rounder mandible, to go along with the Mighty Maid mission statement of nonthreatening curves and coquettish innocence.

A block plane with an attached vacuum tube was applied to the jawbone, Zach assiduously watching the projected ‘after’-visualization on his screen as he absentmindedly joysticked the manipulator back and forth. The peels of bone were sucked off to a repurposing plant, either to be used once again in another Meconstructive process or melted together with other scraps to make realistic decorations for horror-themed branches of the park.

Zach set his sights on the throat next. Though not a strict step in the facial Meconstruction, it was nicer to get it over with right now, and not risk damaging the pretty facade draped over all this ugly bone. A scalpel was applied to the beginning of skin around the neck and drawn downwards, the patient’s eyes still unnervingly fixed towards him.

Zach chose not to let his heebie-jeebies show and instead bothered himself with the adam’s apple. Some women did have it, and indeed, some newly Meconstructed women were allowed to keep theirs — whenever a man was shunted into the Silver Sable role, they generally kept the throat bulge; it looked more intimidating. Mighty Maid would be given no such cartilaginous leeway, however, so the whole thing had to go.

Thankfully, this operation was almost fully automated, for a mistake could leave you with a mute actor, which was about as useful as a Swiss cheese parachute. Zach watched the sharp metal and tweezers shave down the cartilage before descending upon the larynx proper. Glottises of all shapes and sizes are cut to different lengths, pinned, and cut away entirely. A projected simulation of the new Maid’s voice piped “Welcome to WonderWorld!” ad nauseam through Zach’s headphones, differing in pitch, tone, and fry with an incremental adjustment of a dial..

He settled on a breathy, melodic soprano, same as the old Maid. Best to not shake any boats, and it might serve as a little tribute to her. The scalpels and tweezers made the requisite adjustments then moved back, two claws moving in in their place. They draped the lily-white skin up over the mass of blood, stapled muscle, and carved cartilage and smoothed the incision with a line of ointment, leaving an unmarred, swanlike neck, proficient at soft coos and dramatic gasps.

A small alert blared on Zach’s screen. The new face was ready, mounds of muscle and fat covered by a good amount of the subject’s new skin to ensure no ‘tanlines’. Zach summoned a squad of needles filled with neon-bright liquids with a delicate depression of the console, and with another flick, all of them injected their contents into the few muscles still left on the subject’s face, paralyzing any flexable thews that could interfere.

A drawer extended from a cubicle wall, clearing a mass of gel around it. For all the effort gone into it, it simply looked like a detailed masquerade mask, though maybe a little too large to rest on anyone's face.

Zach let out a breath he had been holding for a long while as the arms plucked the face out of its chemical bath. It was nearly over; just the hair and he’d be done. His eyes fell upon the subject’s eyes, still twitching angrily in their sockets.

Maybe there’d be an extra step.
Zach watched bit by bit as the Maid’s new face was layered on; bits of tendons and muscle threaded over the skull and lined affixed with tendons; fat applied strategically with a repurposed pastry tip; and the whole thing lined with an affixative ointment, bringing to Zach’s mind an image of a particularly grotesque cake.

The skin was stretched over the gristle and held there with biodegradable staples, and though it was not quite done yet, Zach couldn’t help but smile. The face was classic Mighty Maid; blue eyes wide enough for eyelashes to flutter diaphanously with every blink; eyebrows arched enough for the most minute raise to broadcast surprise to any onlooker; button nose placed over pert pink lips that parted at rest, flashing the upper row of her impossibly white teeth; and a subtle feminine curve to the whole thing that brought to mind the a young girl’s doll.

Everything was perfectly arranged to create the image of someone who was attractive, but oblivious to that fact. Their — forthcoming — hair could be tousled, their makeup smeared, the whole package wrapped up in a frumpy jersey and sweatpants, but her radiant looks would shine through. That was classic Mighty Maid, heedless of the leers and lecherous gazes she invited simply by going about her day.

The main trick to that effect was inside the manifold strands of sinew underneath the pale dermis. There were a million ways the new thing could smile: a wide delighted grin, a flirty smirk, or the small polite simper of one who hasn’t quite understood what’s just been said. But, in defiance of the adage of a frown using more muscles than a smile, the bands of flesh that were usually used to express disappointment, anger, or sadness were either atrophied, removed, or otherwise weakened. The closest thing to a negative expression that could be, well, expressed was a petulant pout that looked more coquettish than cantankerous.

The new Maid would, unfortunately, develop the requisite muscles for frowning, snarling, anguish, and the like underneath the xenograft, but it would be two or so months before that, long enough for the tallest poppy to be cut to size.

Zach ordered the hair, a chin-length bob of wavy red, that would always diffuse the faint aroma of strawberries. Once again, he met the gaze of the newly-beautified subject. Their eyes crackled threateningly in their paralyzed facade. He heaved a sigh; there was always this kind of sort. You could strip away ⅝ of their body weight, most of their strength, a half-foot of height, and pump ‘em full of soft curves, but they’d still try to bite your ear off the moment they got out.

This would need a solution. Nothing too permanent, just a little fiddling around in their lobes to show them what could happen if they decided to rock the boat. Or just put some little Mighty Maid habits in there to make sure that any consternation would be thoroughly in character. Or he could just coach the poor bugger on what the game’d be when they got out, he'd been through enough for a day.

Zach sighed once again. They didn’t pay him enough to make choices.

1212114213414211211421211132.content:
On a surface level, you appreciate the man’s assistance — having the entire gala stare at you as you writhe on the ground softly moaning isn’t your idea of a best time — but, by way of actually stopping your fit of pleasure, he isn’t helping.

The bouncing of his knee, now intensified, now seems to be for his benefit, as every leg-jerk slides you inch down his inclined leg and closer to his crotch, accompanied by the ever-so-often pinch of your exposed cheeks, which you hadn’t the mental or physical faculties to smooth your tiny skirt over. Add that to the fact that your makeshift gag was distinctly barbecue-flavoured, and that every instance of ‘good-girl’ that he was so intent on murmuring started a fresh fit of pleasure, eliciting more bottom-wiggling and pleasured groans.

The vicious cycle is stopped with a heavy hand on your back pushing you off of his knee and to your wobbly feet. You would squawk in outrage at the man, but most of your mental energy and gaze are directed at your heeled feet, which struggle to find purchase on the floor.

A snap of the fingers draws your gaze upwards to the likely reason you were catapulted off the man’s knee. You meet the indiscernible faces of your maybe-mom and paramour, and then quickly look past them to avoid the tears.

“Yes, we’d like a — what is that in your mouth?!” asks the younger woman. A redness once again rushes to your cheeks as you spit out your gag, partially from embarrassment and partially from the tingles that your apologetic curtsy sends through you.

She stares with open disgust at you before continuing: “Well, anyways, we’d like to order drinks. Do you want to get a pen and paper, or would you try to eat those too, you —”

“Dear!”

She rolls her eyes at the older woman, and continues. “Anyways, I’d like a Capable Cosmopolitan, █████’ll have a Nightcowl Negroni, and, here, █████, the menu...”

She extends her phone to your former massage chair, but he declines it with a smile. “Mighty Mojito, dear.” he smirks. A wink is sent your way. On a whim, you receive it with a silent giggle and an ‘oh you’ hand-swat, and are rewarded with another surge of pleasure.

The older woman titters at the seeming sight of you going weak-kneed at the complement, the younger one scowls, and waves her hand to dismiss you. You comply with a curtsy, and mince off with a spring in your step.

The hall’s layout is almost familiar to you, allowing you to avoid the worst of the swats and gropes, though the few that get through do nothing to dislodge your cargo of dirty dishes. You’re too lost in the pleasant afterglow of whatever was done to you to pay much mind to them or the fact that you were jiggling about for what was most likely your family.

It’s as if your mind is wrapped in cotton as you glide into the kitchen once more, depositing your dirty dish cargo, and placing yourself right next to the swinging doors, hands folded patiently in front of you, bouncing on your heels as well as you can.

“God, you’re perfect,” breathes Zach into your ear. No chemical rush follows the praise though, to your disappointment. You’d pout if you could, maybe then he’d get a —

“Hello? Uh, M&M?”

You startle at the noise, splayed hand flying to your mouth, the warm glow of the action offsetting the shock. The source of your fright is a nervous looking lad in a busboy’s uniform, shaky gaze aimed at your face with heroic effort. He’s taller than you, but you’ve quickly accepted that as a part of your sentence tenure. The name ‘Walter’ is pinned askew on his lapel, which is otherwise uncostumed — a relatively common theme amongst the grunts of the kitchen.

You give a little wave, and his nervous grimace bends into a small smile. “So, uh, what do ya need?”

Grabbing him by the hand — internally grimacing at how his fingers stiffen — and direct his attention to the drink menu on the wall, pointing out the specific ones you aim to collect. You raise your eyebrows at the price — the whole menu together could clean someone out!

The gangly youth nods shakily, the nervous vibration a common theme amongst every motion he takes. “Yup, uh, I can do that. Over here.”

He gestures to the other side of the kitchen, and you trot along there with him, artfully dodging through the sea of waitstaff. You approach a large contraption shaped like a fridge and studded with a wide variety of buttons.

“So, I’ll just, um…” Walter darts off quickly and returns shortly after with an armful of glasses and a large envelope. He busies himself with the buttons, sneaking glances ever-so-often that grow less and less subtle every time. Meanwhile, you’re free to do what you want, a range that’s dwindling second by second.

A tight, familiar panic is burgeoning in your billowy chest with no prickle of pelvic warmth to chase it away. The kitchen is a tight ship, with no maid-shaped niche for you to squeeze into. Your attempt to languidly pick up a dropped fork — and maybe add a little wiggle in for effect — got the utensil snatched out from under your nose for your trouble and a glare leveled at you that evoked a sense of humiliation with no groinal warmth to counterbalance.

But with the clammy sense of shame comes purpose. There’s no man whispering husky compliments into your ear, no maybe-dad cupping and pinching your expansive rear, but the artificial and overwhelming sense of pleasure that they brought in tow was merely a distraction. You needed to get back to that table, maybe borrowing a pad-and-pen from a busboy, so you could —

“Hey, th-the drinks are done.”

give the customers their drinks a good maid would give them their drinks.

You take the round tray Walter offers with a dumb smile and hands trembling from reverence. “One sec,” breathes Walter, doubtlessly confusing himself as the target of your elation. He fumbles with his envelope and produces three laminated pieces of paper, sticking them onto the rims of the cups.

“Y-you’re good to go,” he murmurs. “Do you think that maybe you could — after work of course — mee-”

But you’re already off, your vision captured by the paper resting on the lime-garnished liquor. The other cellulose sheets depict the built-like-a-yield-sign Nightcowl and Captain Capable, but the Mighty Mojito features you.

Red hair tops a cherubic face bent into a smile, coke-bottle-curved body sloping and bulging appropriately, deep cleavage exposed and lassoed with frills. You look down at your own chest-mounted feet-obscurers and giggle mindlessly.

You’re happy, you’re elated, but something in your mind says that’s wrong. Tears sparkle at the edge of one eye, and the other crinkles in delight. You mince haltingly towards the kitchen exit, an odd tango of hesitation and exuberance to serve —

When a supply closet opens up and a rough hand snags you around your hips, dragging you into the closet as you hoarsely squeal in delight/fear.

It’s a miracle that any of the drinks didn’t spill.

12121142134142112114212111323.content:
The rush of being pulled bodily off your feet has a certain rollercoaster-type appeal. A part of delights in the feel of your tiny body being so easily manipulated by a strong, confident hand about your waist.

What is less pleasant is the immediate claustrophobia of the linen closet into which you are pulled. You catch a brief glimpse of stacks of table linen piled to the ceiling and a blur of red, white and blue in the moment before the door is shut behind you, plunging the closet into darkness.

In the pitch black, the hand remains resting in your hip. Behind, the stacks of starched linen press against your backside when you try to take a step back. In front of your face, though you can't see it, you at least sense the impressive physicality of the other body filling the tiny room from wall to wall. Overiding the starch and fabric cleaner, a strong smell of rubber, cologne and masculine aroma assaults your nasal passages.

The sheer size and musculature of the other person shifts the air as they make a small movement with their free hand above your head. "Now where was that thing... so much for infra-red vision... here we go..." comes the smooth, confident voice.

With a flick of a lightswitch, a bare bulb flickers on. It illuminates a wall of contoured blue lycra a centimetre away from your nose. Captain Capable's washboard-like abominable muscles - swollen, cleanly partitioned into an eight-pack with a layer of patriotic costume seemingly sprayed on top - fill your vision.

Craning your head back, you take in the two muscular orbs of his pectorals above you, almost as large as your own, much softer pair. Above them, the World's Mightiest Hero grins down at you, the bare bulb above his head making his curly, golden hair glow like a halo.

"There, that's better, now we can see each other, can't we?" he smirks, his baby blue eyes drinking in the birdseye view down your cleavage. He shifts an inch closer. His abdominals are as hard and unyielding as concrete. Your breasts yield before the immovable object, squashing and bulging up out of the bodice. His smile widens. "And what a sight it is. You're cuter than the last one. From this angle anyway."

His body has you pinned. The pain in your crushed, surgery-raw breasts is intense but worse in the weight on your chest - you can't breath! You struggle for air, each rapid indraw of breath rising your chest higher. The walls seem to press in closer. The bare bulp seems to fill the closet with nauseating, confusing shadows. Even when he takes a step back, your head continues to swim as your breathing increasing in rapidity. Beyond the golden stars emblazoning Capable's uniform, stars begin to glitter on the edge of your vision.

Captain Capable clucks his tongue in realisation. "Yep, those Meconstruction booths will really put you off closed spaces a while." His free right hand slides up under the flimsy uniform, pressing against the flesh. "Your heart is going a mile a minute. Must be terrifying, right? No space - unable to breathe, unable to move, powerless. You can't stop thinking about all those hours trapped in that vat. Even if your body escaped, or parts of it at least, your mind is still in there." Your body has gone limp, supported only by the Captain's hands now, your head lolling like a doll. On the edge of consciousness, you can feel something large and growing larger, pressing against your bare thigh. "Thank your stars I like my damsels in distress. You're having a panic attack. Let me help you with that, cutie."

The Captain leans down, his mint-scented breath whispering in your ear, "Good girl... Excellent customer service... five stars..."

The crushing feeling on your chest starts to lessen as his words trickle into your mind. Drained and washed out, your breathing slows as he continues to soothingly utter, "I'm going to recommend you to all my friends... and give you a huge tip... Such a pretty waitress... so feminine... so delicate... so servile..." His fingers, pressed over your heart, shift. "There, that's better, isn't it? Lucky for you the Captain knows what the ladies like to hear."

Slowly your vision starts to clear. To your surprise, the tray of drinks remains held in your hand, not a drop spilled. Remarkable, considering the rest of your body almost rag-dolled a moment ago, how your arm had continued to hold them as steady and flat as a spirit level... as if operating on separate programming while your mind almost blacked out.

"If you're wondering what I'm doing here..." The Captain plucks the laminated circle from the rim of the Capable Cosmopolitan, admiring the image of himself on it, before replacing it. "... I was summoned by a guest. Looks like they want you too." He snags the cellulose coin of Nightcowl from its drink, scowling at it as if wanting to crush the thing within his fist. "Looks like Nightcowl will be here soon too. Which gives me just enough time for..."

1214.content:
Nightcowl:
The resident brooding powerless member of the Utopian alliance, this tall-dark-and-edgy character spends most of his time roaming the dark alleyways of Wonder-City, beating up common thugs (i.e. extras) and only occasionally meeting the eyes of a superfan Guest.

A relatively easy job as far as Actors go, but the spotlight never shines quite as brightly in the seedy underbelly. Plus, they have to deal with Brighteyes…

Brighteyes:
The Wondertainment-mandated perky sidekick to Nightcowl, this role is the most malleable of all of WonderWorld’s! Depending on the direction that the Writers decide to take the plot, this bushy-tailed being could be a girl, boy, tall, short, any ethnicity under the sun, smart, dumb, etc.

Of course, Wondertainment would never shell out the amount of money it would take to hire separate actors for each one, so whichever sorry sap gets the role has to spend quite a lot of time in a Meconstruction booth.

Ergo, most Brighteyes’ are a bit… unstable. You don’t get a turnover rate that high without a reason, after all.

Fantasti-Lass:
The first thing that someone might notice about Captain Capable’s own sidekick — alter ego dubbed Audrey Palmer — is how darn cute she is.

Five feet three inches of cuddly dynamite; the smattering of freckles over her face; the bit-too-bulky black boots and gloves; and, of course, the black pair of super-underoos over her bright yellow spandex costume. All of it ties together to create one of the friendliest faces of Wonder-City! (Behind the Captain himself, of course.)

Those who are looking with a more lasivicious eye, perhaps, might notice the set of flotation devices anchored to her chest.

It was a little in-joke pulled by the artist of her issues: drawing her chest just a litttle bigger each issue to see what he could get away with — executives only noticed when her endowments were near-head-sized. By then, the sales were too high to justify any rollbacks: a spandex-clad pair of baps skyrocketed demands among the teenage demographic.

The curvy coed was put in WonderCity for much of the reason as Mighty Maid: another soft body for monied Guests to grope, but fate had a different idea in mind for the Golden Girl of WonderCity…

It turned out that ages 4-9 just loved the Lass. Maybe their eyes were drawn to the overabundance of nonthreatening yellow; maybe her short stature seems to be a common denominator for the precocious picknies — the reason didn’t quite matter. All that Wondertainment was able to suss out was that she made an excellent daycare manager while the parents were off engaging in salacious superheroics.

Even the most twisted tycoon balks a bit at feeling up the lass you're leaving your kids alone with.

So, just pop the most motherly graduate in the overbuxom form of Audrey and you’re off to the races, right?

Of course not.

Wondertainment wants its roles — and consequently, the actors forced into them — to be flexible. What’s the point of just having a simple babysitter when you can have her work double-time as an understudy?

It’s well-known that only one graduate gets to be the star of the show, the Captain himself. But, of course, you’re going to have a runner-up or two. So, shove the second bananas into the sidekick, and bang, presto, you have a perfectly personnel-efficient part! It’s a bit on-the-nose; both actor and their sidekicked-role learning at the Captain’s side.

What’s that? Placing some of the most ambitious graduates in a bit part that’s only made of sweet smiles, endearing naiveté, bending over backwards for rich brats, and near-constant backpain might create a deep-seated resentment towards their more-successful Captain counterparts?

That’s ridiculous.

You’ve never quite liked flights. Being packed into a tube like so many sardines is upsetting enough, but having the damn thing twist and rumble and pop your ears through the whole ordeal is just icing on the shit-cake.

At least I got the window seat, you morosely think. The view isn’t half bad, starting with the triangular Wonder-Res—

“Oh, that’s the Wonder-Resort! ” a voice to your right practically shouts into your ear. Before you can plead for him to calm down, your dad has intruded directly into your personal space, craning his head directly over the book you were reading and resting his arms on your armrest.

He turns his bearded face to you, eyes gleaming, and more needless trivia spews out of his mouth. “Did you know that they have special transport to each borough there? There’s a rocket-shaped magnet-train for Wonder-Galaxy, a horse-drawn carriage for Wonder-Kingdom, and a…”

You try your best to tune him out by turning up the volume for your in-flight entertainment — all Wondertainment media, not that you expected anything different — and you watch your dad’s jaw jabber up and down. You’d shoot a ‘Who cares?’ or ‘God can you be quiet?’ in his direction, but you have enough experience with your father to know it’d have little to no effect on him

Instead of having a somewhat interesting hobby like prostitutes or drugs, your dad had become fascinated with nerdery.

And what’s worse, he was a nerd for Wondertainment Studios. The very same company that churned out roughly eighty percent of the world’s most insipid entertainment and bought out the schmucks who produced the rest of that superlative. You hadn’t really paid attention in Econ — you instead made yourself busy exchanging moon-eyes and notes with Zoe, a girl you rather fancied — but you were pretty sure that some anti-trust whatevers aren't being enforced. Or something.

And what’s worst is that he likes the old stuff. The sword and sandals live-action shows and cartoons of the eighties, or sci-fi dreck with the ‘aliens’ made up in rubber prosthetics and three inches of makeup. You could barely change a channel without an aside glance and a scoff from your pop, about how “This is nothing like what they had when I was your age.”

His company had a sales contest that he was utterly disinterested in till the grand prize was announced; a two-person trip to WonderWorld; and some sort of special package at that. You had never seen him work like that before and the way he looked by the end of the whole rigmarole — eyes ringed with dark circles, a forest of stubble across his face, and his voice hoarse from all the calls he made. But he had won, and thus sealed your fate.

The last you had seen of your house was your mom’s sympathetic eyes gazing at you from the window; most of your mother-son bonding time was through the shared misery of the family costumes he forced you into for some esoteric convention.

You risk a look at your dad’s seat, but thankfully, his attention is off you or the window. Unfortunately, he’s watching one of his favorite shows, the reason you took this trip. You stifle a sigh.

On your dad’s back-seat screen, a leather-jacketed man shifts a throttle forward and grins roguishly at the camera. You roll your eyes and let out a groan that your pop thankfully doesn’t notice. God, he must’ve played this about a thousand times.

The man on screen is Dylas Canthrope, the hero of Universal Odyssey, the show that your dad had devoted roughly a third of his life to. A two seasoned series that ‘was cut down in its prime’ according to your dad, it followed the pompadoured space-pirate as he roamed across galaxies, thwarting the nebulous Hegemony and helping out various alien species in a way that wasn’t very pirate-like at all.

Your dad’s grin widens as he watches Dylas point imperiously at his co-pilot seat. Its shapely occupant snaps into a smart salute and minces over to the engine room to stabilize the positronic flux thingamijigs or whatever.

That character, who went by the consonant-covered moniker of Cjara, was the only reason you stomached that show anymore. A petite, mostly-sapient gynoid, you suspect that she was primarily created so the crew could watch the actress cavort around in thigh-high boots and a high-legged leotard. You envy the makeup artist who got to gussy her up in gold metallic paint.

As a child, you had made the mistake of asking why a robot needed to look human and have all the requisite jiggly bits, and your dad answered your question with a detailed description of the servos and gyroscopes in her base that just happened to resemble wide hips, and of course because she’s a pilot she needs to have a good deal of gel padding, for inertia and all that.

You suspected that dad appreciated the show for something other than its rich worldbuilding, and your suspicions were deepened by the traces of golden paint on your mom’s face the night after their anniversary.

You turn your attention back to your book, but whatever interest you can find pales in comparison to what you can see out the window. The embers of filial affection flare up a bit in your chest, and you tap at your dad’s shoulder.

“Look at that,” you breathe, staring at the massive Dysonian sphere that looks to be only a thousand feet below your metal tube. Your dad joins you in goggling, thankfully silent, as you admire the mega-structure. You may not like Wondertainment, but even you have to cop to brilliance.

“That’s where we’re going,” your dad crows, his eyes shining. “WonderGalaxy. There’s more than ‘a hundred little locales in there, each a little slice of an alien world.” He taps his seat-screen demonstratively, where Dylas and Cjara are stumbling around unconvincingly — an asteroid had struck their clunker, apparently.

“The company shelled out for the ‘Part of the Experience’ package, too, so this is gonna be extra special.” He lightly punches you on the arm and grins, and you magnanimously allow it. “Just you and me, sport, traveling the galaxy!”

You return his toothy grin with a rare smile of your own.

This might actually be pretty cool.

14314.content:
Your burgeoning excitement is jostled from your mind by a series of jerks and precipitous drops from the plane. Your seatbelt is buckled even before the seatbelt sign winks on.

"Ladies and Gentlemen, this is your uh Captain speaking. We uhh apologise for the slight turbulence. We are encountering stronger thermals rising from the WonderGalaxy dome than usual, and are recalculating our landing vector to avoid them. Uhhh, as we should be landing in a little under 20 minutes, we ask you to remain in your seats for the remainder of the journey. Thank you."

The plane banks to the right, the steel geodesic sphere dropping from view as the window swings nauseatingly upwards at a clear, blue sky. Not content just to create its own microclimate within the WonderGalaxy, the sheer scale of the construction has caused ecological chaos for the local wildlife. The sunlight that reflects from the polished metal is said to cook any wildlife that strays too close and has created a desert out of the lagoon for a half mile radius, while the hot air rising from the sun-baked metal is enough to set planes quivering a thousand feet up. There are stories that Wondertainment had been forced to relocate the carpark after the sheer, focused sunlight melted a car.

That's Wondertainment in a nutshell. Audacious, with enough money to trample any legislation or common sense that gets in their way, and totally uncaring of the consequences.

The plane flattens out. Pushing your head back in to the headrest, you fixate on a point directly head, trying to blot out the sloshing in your stomach and your ear canals. You clench your stomach to stop the bile from rolling up into your throat.

"Relax," dad crows, even as the plane rattles like a tin can. "These things are engineered for way worse turbulence than this."

"The same engineers that built a theme park that can cook an alligator at 200 meters?" you retort.

In an attempt to take your mind of your situation, you switch your focus to the show still playing on dad's back-seat screen. Perhaps that was a bad idea - Dylas and Cjara throw themselves around in their seats, as their command consoles burst with sparks and smoke. Shields were, as they permanently appeared to be, at 13%.

"How come the actors are shaking about but the golden dice hanging from the console aren't?" you ask, pointing an accusatory finger at the obvious gaff. "Don't they have the laws of physics in the 31st Millennium?"

Dad points with finger-guns (or finger-phasers), doing his best imitation of Dylas Canthrope roguish mannerisms as he quips "laws don't apply to Dylas Canthrope." You roll your eyes.

On screen, a sleek fighter bears down on Dylas Canthrope's ship, guns strobing. A shot from within the cockpit shows what you suspect to be an out-of-work porn actress from the 1960s, slathered in green paint and KY jelly and practically poured into a silver catsuit.

"How about those for physics?" dad says with a wink and a nod at her bountiful breasts sloshing about, barely contained, while what is clearly the arm of a stagehand wobbles the set from side to side. "Gelatina: the most sensual single-celled organism in the Galaxy. One of Canthrope's most persistent nemeses - well, she was in two episodes anyway." He jabs a finger at her glistening, green tits. "See, a lot of people complain that her outfit was exploitative, but its actually designed to maintain her shape - in her natural form she's a shapeless amoebae. The science is all there in the Universal Odyssey: Insider's Guide."

"Uh huh. What's her deal?" you ask, fishing around for a question to appear genuinely interested in the subject matter after realising you've been staring at a (probably long dead) actress' breasts for far longer than is socially acceptable.

"She's a Space Marshall - it's her job to bring Dylas in. She aint bad but she's got one hell of a stick up her butt. See, she's terrified that if she ever relaxes, she'll lose her form completely and turn into primordial goo. That's why she's so uptight."

"Seems a little..." Your thoughts are derailed as a proton torpedo collides with Gelatina's fighter, sending fresh quakes through the actress. "Is,uh, she at the park?"

Still though, your gaze is firmly affixed on Gelatina, or more accurately, her wobbling bust. Thank you very much for flying on Magical Airlines, and feel free to leave us a review on the Wonderapp if you enjoyed this flight.” A bit of rattling filters through the speakers. “God, Joe, I didn’t think we were gonna make it…”

Large murals line the walls, classic and new-fangled Wondertainment characters all depicted in neon-bright colours. Trolls stand next to space aliens, and princesses in poofy gowns are placed unusually close to spandex-clad superheroes.

“What a mess,” you mumble, as you heft your carry-on past the lip of the bridge.

her attention is quickly drawn by your dad.

"I won the vacation, I determine the adventure."

The attendant returned with two clipboards of sheets, both of which were swiftly intercepted by your father.

"You're in the resort too?"

You pop the pill and wash it down. You unfold the plastic bag and, feeling like an idiot, place it on the floor and step into it, drawing it up your body and sealing it with the hermetic zipper. Feeling like somebody's packed lunch, you sit and wait for the representative to return. Your breath mists the inside of the bag, and it soon starts to get humid and close inside.

Is this safe? Don't you need air holes? You distinctly recall multiple teachers and parents telling you not to do this exact thing in your young life.

"God, I look dumb," you mutter. But what comes out is "gawg guy gluk dung." Your tongue sits strangely in your mouth - it feels numb, sluggish and bloated. "Wah dah fug?" Your whole jaw feels loose and hangs open, a line of drool dribbling out.

There's a queasy feeling in your stomach, as though that tiny pill is effervescing into tingling bubbles that are spreading out through your torso. You place a hand on your gut. The flesh there feels... soft. You're not saying you've ever boasted washboard abs or anything, but your fingers seem to press into the skin like you're kneading dough. Pulling your shirt up, you stare at the indentations of your fingers pressed into the flesh around your belly button.

This is precisely why they say to keep kids away from plastic bags! Yet when you try to grab the zipper, your fingers are too numb to manipulate it. You wrap your fingers around the the index finger of your right hand and try to rub some sensation back into them.

The moment you apply pressure, the flesh in your finger flows to the tip of the finger in a bulge, like toothpaste being pushed down a tube. You're vaguely aware you're starting to scream as you try to squash the bulbous end of your finger back down into something resembling a finger. Your attempts only worsen things. The flesh under the skin is getting softer and softer, running like jelly, and as you try to squash the digit back into shape, it soon resembles the knobbly creation of a baby with play-doh.

There is a sickening crunch-squelch from your knees, and your height drops by inches. Your trousers are beginning to stretch outwards, as if your legs are melting and sinking into themselves.

You try desperately to tear your way free. The plastic is tough and even your fingernails are soft. You try to bite your way out. Your teeth have all the consistency of gummy bears. A weakness permeates every muscle. You can barely gather the strength to lift an arm.

Under the weight of your torso, your legs have concertina's to a third of their height. To your horror, the flesh of your leg starts to gloop from out of the hem of your trousers, like hot wax. There is no doubt about it now - you're melting!

Your head is sinking in to your double, then triple, then quadruple chin, which in turn sinks into your neck, which is becoming one with your torso. There is a churning, boiling feeling inside of your internal organs liquefying.

Not exactly filled with hope but desperate to get out of here, you try to take a step and, despite the fact that your legs are now melted beyond all use, your entire body seems to surge forward against the walls of the bag, which rolls forward. Like a hamster rolling in a ball, you continue to push and the sealed bag (now more closely resembling a misshapen, flesh-coloured blob with a face) rolls out of the cubicle.

This is actually becoming easier, you think after a few more tentative rolls, not noticing that the rolling of the bag is churning up your body even further, like a trifle in a washing machine, mixing your clothes, your phone, your wallet, and your rapidly-liquefying limbs, torso and head together into a thick soup. You look around desperately for help, anyone but that evil woman who gave you the pill! 1431411115.content:
The maybe-adrenaline running through your goop-veins keeps your ungainful trundling steady as you inch towards the WonderGalaxy sign, a bright neon thing flanked by flickering fluorescent stars. Your dad’s the one who knows science fiction shit, right? He can fix this. Probably. Maybe.

Upsettingly, one of your eyes has drifted to near the back of your curvature, giving you a full view of your erstwhile-mini-crush chasing after you. Fortunately, she seems to be inept at running in heels as you are at rolling, so you’re able to maintain your lead. She stumbles into a tank of startled mermaids as your eye drifts back to the front.

You slop onto the travelator with a satisfied gurgle. You’re home, er, galaxy free. You sidle closer to the side to avoid the busybodies walking down the grid and relax whatever you can still relax, sending the melted stub of your nose off to god knows where.

But, just as you’re thinking of the title of your tell-all memoir about the sordid workings of WonderWorld, you stop. You oscillate in confusion. Then, you see it.

A wide exhibit of various spacey Wondertainment properties lies ahead of you, with a motley group of aliens and jumpsuitted humans gathered at each one. But, more importantly, the travelator has stopped. Your bag is curling itself into the landing platform, inexorably inching you towards the dreaded gap.

You burble in panic and throw yourself against the far end of the bag, but to no avail. You’re pulled towards your gummy fate, clogging the mechanisms of some awful treadmill in the world’s shittiest theme park.

It can’t end like this! You haven’t even been laid!

“Got ya, little shit.”

Your burble of supplication is interrupted by a sharp tug on your plastic prison. Another one shortly follows, and you plastic prison suddenly jostles itself out of the sticky situation. You wriggle your mass in a circle to view and maybe communicate thanks to your savior, but the shapeless mass of goo that your heart now is plummets.

Gena Nova towers above you, her pretty face etched with anger. Aside her stands a man whose uniform ripples with muscle, his forehead ridged with what appears to be bone. He holds your bag a foot above the travelator’s crevice with one thick arm.

Nova turns to the exhibit quickly, plastering a winning smile on her mug. “Sorry, for the disturbance, all. Me and the ensign,” She gestures to the strongman beside her and he returns a look of vague offense, “had to catch a rogue Ameboid!”

You launch yourself against the walls of the bag, trying to share your desperation to the crowd, but they only smile briefly at the display before looking away. Gena waves to them sweetly as she struts to and through a door marked ‘STAFF ONLY’, the ‘ensign’ following shortly after.

Her facade of corporate cheer sloughs off her face the moment the door clunks shut, balling her fists at her side and adding a stomp to her step that echoes down the concrete hallway.

The view is warped and flesh-coloured through the plastic walls and your own semi-transparent, jelly-like body, now that your eyes are sloshing about somewhere within you, but you can see what looks to be a wet room. The tiled walls have none of the sheen of the visitor area, splattered with grime and multicoloured stains. The worktops set around the walls contain implements of all sorts, and tubs and jars of chemicals. From the ceiling, hang what appear to be cybernetic limbs and other sci-fi props.

"Let's get the kid finished up quick. Can't have the dad missing his squeeze. Get it? Squeeze?" Nova leers, grabbing a handful of your plastic-encased flesh and squashing it between her fingers.

As you pour and settle into the container, a hand squeezes through the aperture above. The sensation of it sinking through your flesh, of your own body contracting about their wrist, is more alien than any of the rubber-headed aliens staffing the gates to Galaxy World, but not entirely unpleasant. A quiver of pleasure ripples through you as the delicate fingers sweep and search within you. They snag your twisted, sodden t-shirt. The feeling of the rough fabric being ripped from your insides is much less pleasant.

Gena shrieks and slams something flat and hard down on your appendage, which bursts, showering her in goo. You cringe your pseudopod back inside like a snail retreating into its shell.

143141111512.content:
You lost your mouth a good while ago. Along with your nose. And your ears. And the rest of your favorite orifices.

So, considering all that, it’s some perverse miracle of science or magic or whatever the hell is going on that you still have the use of all five senses.

You can taste and smell the metallic walls of your cell mixed with the odd chemical scent of the unidentified liquids within you; you can feel the whirring blades and bits of phone plastic as your surprisingly durable eyes bounce off them; and you can hear the cacophonous grind of the blender’s motors.

It’s all you can do to concentrate on each bit of every sensation to truss together your disintegrating psyche, along with the prospect of revenging yourself on the Junior Lieutenant.

You focus on the image that your scattered synapses produce: Gena’s face streaked with fat tears, desperately hurling apologies in your direction as her wrists are slapped with space-manacles, and she’s dragged off to space-jail.

You’re on the third episode of these imaginings — Nova is being ‘disciplined’ by the warden for brewing waste-disposal-chute wine — when the blades scything through you come to a halt. A slow bubble rises through your mass to join the tingly froth that rests on your surface.

Everything is dark. Whatever you use to smell has long grown used to the potpourri of flower-fascimile and metal. You almost long for the blender to start up again, to put an end to this awful, painful stillness.

Light suddenly illuminates your prison, a small hole in the bottom letting a dim green illuminate your small cube. You will yourself towards it, but no motion whips your ameboid body into action. The thin membrane you used for movement has been shredded into tiny bubbles. This troubling fact established, you swirl down the hole with an accompanying gloop.

You flow through a series of bends, the light getting stronger with every second and a vague sound echoing, until you spurt out into air with an unceremonious phrrt.

The first thing that you notice as you fall is the bright red and yellow uniforms of Gena and — you assume — Derek. They’re huddled around a large console that, in lieu of an actual keyboard, has a trackball, brightly colored arrows, and a ball-top joystick. They’re in the throes of an hands-waving, red-faced whispered argument, but they both stop momentarily to look at you spout out of your spigot: Derek with wry amusement, Gena with a contemptuous sneer.

The second thing you notice is what you’re actually settling into. It’s a shiny silver catsuit that’s standing up as if starched. A badge that matches Nova’s rests right above the breast, which bulges outwards presumably in anticipation of a well-endowed occupant, the front-facing zipper not quite reaching all the way up to the neck. Boots are built-in to the outfit, the heels impractically high.

You’re once again treated to the nauseating experience of split vision, one eye sinking past the narrow waist and settling in the green tinted bulge of a shaped buttock, the other bobbing at the top of your volume, peeking out of the deep scoop neck.

You’d shiver if you could. Was this what you were a part of now? A Wondertainment conspiracy to turn teenage boys into catsuit-lube? You concentrate as hard as you can and try to flex your cytoplasm, but the expected nothing happens. At least you’d get to be pressed up against a naked female body in your last moments.

The gruesome twosome’s argument reaches a coherent volume. You swivel your eye to view them.

“They’re big,” hisses Gena, cupping two hands in front of her chest. “Never-see-your-feet-again big! He drew it, I checked the show, just listen to me, for Chrissake!”

The rugged man snorts. “Yeah right. Misery loves company, Gene, and you’re a miserable sod.”

Gena purples for a second, then coldly fiddles with the console. You can’t quite make out what’s on the screen — it looks like a kind of silver-green smear from here — but it evidently has Derek impressed, if the curve of his ridged brow is anything to judge.

“Wow,” he breathes. “Guess it was a different time back then.”

“Told you so.” crows Nova. The two confer a bit more, before once again shifting their gaze to you. Once again, you fail to shiver. Nova’s smug smirk switches to a predatory leer as she stalks towards you.

“Oh, I’m going to enjoy this.”
