1432.content:
A cel-shaded figure sashays across the LCD screen, wrists precipitously limped, bell-curve hips pivoting wildly. She’s clad in a pink dress that’s an odd mix of clingy and poofy with a neckline that practically plunges to her navel and a hemline that barely reaches her thigh. Two large masses of ballast practically yank her forward with every swish, and the long pointy ears that stand out against her long mane of blonde currently are flattened against her head like a scolded dog.

You sigh in disgust, but you continue your scrutiny of the animated figure. Your ethos of general parent-scorning insists that you avert your gaze and maybe throw a sneer your dad’s way, but your teenage libido insists that your eyes remain on the screen.

Out of the corner of your eye, you can see your dad in a similar state of observation, streamers of drool practically hanging from his mouth. You’re not particularly sure why he’s so engaged; he must’ve seen this a thousand times.

The show is ‘Legend of the Hallowed Lands,’ a kitschy pulp-fantasy cartoon-anthology series made primarily to sell toys, and the voluptuous elven figure on screen is called Princess Allaria, a functionally useless twit of a ruler.

Well, not that useless; her voluptuous figure and vague wisps of clothing were probably the only reason the show has lasted long enough in the public consciousness to be purchased by Wondertainment.

The on-screen princess is currently overcome with emotion, slamming her tiny fists against her ornate fluffy bed, big blue eyes teary and her chest heaving like a roiling sea. You frown; you’re normally all for watching a billowing bosom, but only if it’s an earned chest-oscilation. According to the subtitles, all Allaria had been through so far was a snide comment on her dress.

Your mental grandstanding is almost immediately contradicted as you affix your eyes on yet another bouncy fit of hysterics, the busty elf covering an exaggerated gasp with a dainty hand while the twin mountains on her chest wobble like puddings. She’s received a letter from an admirer and her demeanor has switched from soul-crushing-despair to tittering jubilation.

“Does she ever stop?” you moan, a bit of your breakfast from five hours ago nearly escaping your stomach with another jolt of the plane.

Your dad rolls his eyes in response. “Clearly someone doesn’t understand the perils of court life. The wrong choice in dress could mean a lifetime of obscurity in the decadent courts of Tyr.”

“Yeah, that’s why you watch this show,” you retort. “The gripping political intrigue.”

Your argument is interrupted by the on-screen princess mincing over to her anachronistic modern walk-in closet and unlacing her corset, the curvature of the orbs visible from behind her back—

And the scene abruptly cuts to some generic teen hero swording and sorcery-ing a horde of knobbly-kneed goblins.

“How did this air?” you ask, after overcoming the staggering sense of disappointment.

“Times were different back then,” your dad sighs wistfully. “Less rating agencies and board of executives, more passion and dreams.”

You raise your eyebrows at the remark, but let it pass unretorted. Better to let him reminisce rather than suffer through a tirade of how her bi-episodic kidnappings are central to her character arc.

The plane screen flickers and your stomach spins in circles as the plane banks to the left. You rest a hand on the window and stare fervently at it to stave off the worst of your motion sickness, but are only greeted with something that makes you sicker. Just, uh, ideological-wise.

Large swathes of fluffy green coat the ground, interspersed by small smatterings of houses, varied in size and roofing choice. Small antlike wagons clatter along dusty roads from larger settlements, each wildly different than the others. One is built on a lagoon, each building separated from the other with reservoirs of clear blue; another is hewn out of stone, with small squat prisms of rock presumably serving as houses. The entire mass of land is so big that it extends beyond the narrow aperture of your window.

It looks like a Luddite’s wet dream, and you might be able to muster a few seconds of widened eyes if it was hand-built. But this is Wondertainment, after all. The trees are nature-defying constructions of concrete with tarpaulin leaves; the lagoon-city doubtless scented with tonnes of chlorine and artificial blue coloring; the entire mountain citadel a dun mass of plaster.

This is WonderKingdom, a branch of WonderWorld that decided to crib a fair bit of its InterStoryStructure™ — God knows what that means — from tabletop games and RPGs, with a dizzying array of guilds, good-guys, and baddies of conflicting themes and allegiances, with some quest-based system to put some extra confusion in the mix.

In short, it’s a nerd’s paradise, which means your dad is beyond amped to be here, judging by the leg adjacent to you that’s practically vibrating. You discreetly follow his gaze to a particularly large tree, one that you can recognize from a brief establishing shot on his TV screen.

Huh. At least you might get some topheavy elven eye-candy on this waste of a spring break.

The patchwork landscape grows closer, furlong by dizzying furlong. The runway you appear to be descending towards is disconcertingly tan and dusty, but the harried flight attendant that you hail down assures you that it’s faux-dirt, for authenticity.

You cling onto that promise almost as tightly as your armrest as the pilot chirps the ubiquitous landing spiel. Your dad has been and remains enviably asleep throughout this entire ordeal — likely sleeping off the few cocktails he had ordered mid-flight, the lucky bastard.

“Wake up, Rob.”

“mghrrfump” Waking up seems bad. Sleep is better. No planes in dreamland.

“Wake up, or I’ll send your middle-school photos to that girl you like.”

Your eyes shoot open and almost immediately punish you for opening them. Everything is bright. As your pupils slowly contract, you’re greeted with the unpleasant sight of your father gazing impatiently down at you, and the equally unpleasant sight of the WonderKingdom airport terminal.

As with all of Wonderworld’s boroughs, WonderKingdom is carefully curated to ensure maximum immersion. But because the WonderKingdom experience starts at landing on the artificial island, the airport has been interjaculated with the horribly high-fantasy gimmick that it prides itself on. Stalls line the walls in the stead of stores, offering greasy meat-products or gimmicky jewelry, all purchasable with the local currency of faux metal coins. Knights line the security gates in lieu of TSA agents whilst a harried employee garbed in traditional star-and-moon wizard robes waves a magic wand over queue waiters. The roof looks to be made of wood and straw, and you pray that the latest jet departure doesn’t whip it off.

Tapestries hang from the walls depicting Wondertainment fantasy media, though, disappointingly, the only glimpse of Allaria you can catch is her knife-eared head in ¾ profile, her wide blue eyes narrowed and plump lips twisted into a pout, all in a feeble attempt at authority. You guess that it wouldn’t probably do well for publicity if a full-figured portrait of the lush lass festooned the welcoming walls.

“Yeah, yeah, cool isn’t it,” your dad mumbles. Before you can assure him that it isn’t at all cool, he slaps you on the shoulder and starts to crab walk away. “Need ta use the little adventurer’s room. Piss out a couple brews.”

“What am I supposed to do?”

Your dad stops his hasty egress for a second to hook a thumb a ways off to your left. You follow the invisible line to a figure in puffy-panted jester’s garb. A smile is plastered on a face that you would describe as elfin if it weren’t too on-the-nose, any lock of hair concealed by the belled hat. They stand half a foot below you and are frighteningly androgynous, but you assume she’s a woman, for convenience

“‘ello there, acolyte adventurer! I’m Jingle the Jester, your guide to the Wondertastic World of WonderKingdom!”

You wince at the cacophonous greeting. “Yeah, uh, nice to meet you..” You scratch the back of your head and desperately scan the room for Dad. “Is there… anyone else here to greet us?”

She gives an animated shake of her head, sounding a light tinkle from her belled cap. “‘Fraid not, sirrah! Just little ol’ Jingle! Follow along carefully now!”

She beckons you forward with a rainbow-gloved hand, and you do your best to turn your grimace into a polite smile as you comply.

~~~


The last fifteen minutes could perhaps qualify for the ‘most mind-numbing’ superlative. A squeaky-voiced harlequin — who didn’t even have the good manners to be nice to look at — coaching you on the lore of this insipid place? Your dad’s wet dream, probably, but worse than a root canal for you.

Most of your time is spent shooting jealous glares at the Hawaiian-shirted tourist who’ve been lucky enough to have an elf clad in a skimpy leaf camisole point animatedly out the window at a giant tree, or a duo of amazons in matching chainmail bikini explain the minutiae of the token-based economy. You catch some hastily spoken words from Jingle: ‘Implicit Waiver’ and ‘legally binding tacit agreement’, but the rest of her spiel goes one ear and out the other.


You only snap back to the present when the pesky Pierrot waves a sheaf of faux-yellowed parchment in your face.

“Whackthp is it?!” you splutter through the sheets of cellulose.

“A character sheet, sirrah!” Her smile is nauseatingly sweet. “One o’ ya ordered the premium package!”

“And those are…?”

“A carnet to a fantastic, authentic WonderKingdom experience!” Great, more sonnets instead of straight answers. You’d ask what she actually means, but you don’t want to open that can of verse-spouting worms.

You flip through the sheets, where a dizzying amount of stats, description boxes, ‘drawing reference’, and a spell list all greet you, all empty lines that, you realize with a shudder, you are supposed to lace with words.

“Am I supposed to fill in… all this?”

Another tinkling nod. “Right you are! No need to make haste!”

Your face pales. There is a need to make haste. If Dad gets back before each and every category is filled in, you’ll never leave this airport. You squint at each category vaguely, not even sure of what you’re supposed to be writing for. Some kind of companion? Is an actor going to follow you around, spouting lines from some esoteric 80s show?

Wait.

“Uh, can I put, like, an existing character in this?” You ask, nearly dropping a page in your haste.

“Certainly, sirrah! Second-to-last page!”

You see it. A refreshingly succinct page, only containing a simple ‘Character Name,’ Guest Name,’ and… ‘Roleplaying Aid’?’

“What does this mean?”

Jingle tilts her head in a manner that she appears to think conveys friendliness, but it more closely resembles a psychotic mannequin. “Ah, that’s just a little rigamarole we put the ol’ box ‘neath to make sure everythin’s context sensitive,” She punctuates the last two words with a jostle of her bells and a tap of her head. “No point in havin’ a ‘You’ or ‘Why’ when a ‘Thou’ or ‘Wherefore’ ‘ll do!”

You return a hesitant nod. By the sound of it, they’ll send out a theater kid. A weird one, by the sound of it.

“Hey Rob! What’re chatting up the clown for?!”

A finger of ice creeps up your spine. A peek over your shoulder reveals your dad, bowleggedly hobbling his way back from the bathroom. Quick as a flash, you write the only character you know on the form — Allaria Seraphina — and pause on the next line.

It would be nice to have a busty elf cling to your arm for the duration of the trip, but on the other hand, your dad might actually attempt filicide if he susses out your secret. And sure, you might be able to suss out a grope or two if you give ‘prima nocta to your pop, but it wouldn’t feel quite the same...

Hastily, you write ____, and shove it into Jingle’s gloved hands.
14322.title: Landing at a weird medieval-themed airport.

choices: Chose the third option - start as yourself but unlock new abilities as you go
143221.content:
Jingle produces a slim, leather-bound tome and opens it on the central page. A square has been cut out of the glued-together pages to insert a handheld document scanner. She slips the parchment face-down on the glassy surface, snapping the tome shut again.

"The contract signed, the quest begins, the odds seem insurmountable! Wondertainment accepts this waiver, and can't be held accountable!" she proclaims.

"Rob, you didn't!" dad whines, his face falling. "I had plans! Years of D&D characters. You don't even know the lore..." He turns to Jingles, for a moment looking ready to snatch the tome and parchment out of her hands, but the jester gives a surprisingly nimble hop backwards with a clattering of bells. "Tell me I get a do-over."

"Do-over? Nay, the ink is dry, what's done is done is done! Hush now, Princess, don't you cry, just try to have some fun!"

"'Princess'?" dad gasps, his face paling.

"We-well, you... always did have a soft spot for elves," you reply weakly.

Gamboling over to him, Jingles prods him in his fleshy chest with a stave spiraled with coloured streamers. "Soft spots, aye, it's fair to say she'll have those in abundance! They'll serve you well, more than 'er, when lost within dark dungeons!"

"Not. Helping," you hiss.

"But surely you couldn't possibly make an elf out of me?" dad splutters, hoisting his beer gut for emphasis.

Raising her bright stave and giving a sharp flick of it, the amazonian duo breaks away from their client and moves across the concourse towards dad. Jester titters and capers about him, seizing handfuls of his belly fat in her hands. Her whole demeanor has changed upon the signing of the contract, becoming suddenly impish. "Our apothecaries, skilled in their arts, for guests they do outdo! Why, there's flesh enough for not one elf, I'm sure they could make two!"

She finishes her rhyme with a leering, lopsided grin up at him. As the amazons take their places at his elbows, Jingles raises her fist to her lips, unfurls it, and blows, a cloud of magenta glitter hitting him full in the face. His head snaps back as if struck by a heavy object and he falls, unconscious, into the waiting arms of the warrior women. His sandals scrape against the floor as he is dragged bodily away.

"Is he going to be okay?" you fret.

"Paternal flesh, they will contort, come dawn he'll make a comely consort."

"Consort? Hey, I never said that I wanted a- a -"

"You ticked the box for roleplay aid, you'll find her more than just context sensitive," Jingles crows with a wink. "Your own obedient, winsome maid - try not to look so pensative. This world is yours, and all within. To take, to seize, to win! And she'll soon take her role as well; once you fill her in..."

With a deranged smile, Jingles pushes a second piece of parchment into your hands. Its edges are gilded, and it is addressed to the owner of the 'Premium Package'. It is similar to the last - a slot open for your character description, the option for a premade, or a third option...
143221.title: Your dad’s name, with Roleplaying Aid

choices: Looking — and being disappointed — at your 'character's' stats.
Things seem to be... off, as you ride to your destination.
1432214.content:
Your eyes scan the faux-parchment with alacrity. It is shaken emphatically, its holder’s bell-wrists jingling in time.

“Come now, young sir, there’s no time to balk,” warns the jester. “Can you hear that? It’s the tick of the clock!”

“Shut up, I’m thinking!” you shoot back, scanning the page over and over again. Each innocuous description now seems laden with sinister meaning. You eye the sculpted backs of the amazons as they enter a swinging door disguised as brick and mortar. Are they what passes for a ‘martial class’? Could stroke of the pen could confine you to a similarly striated form, or worse, a similarly buxom, pointy-eared fate to match your dad’s?

Jingle’s grin stays wide and manic as you fret over the options. Well, for the first two minutes of fretting. By the third, it’s switched to a small smirk, and by the fifth, any trace of mirth has been wiped off her face.

Your desperate rereading is interrupted by a finger slamming onto the page, which is lowered to reveal the humorist’s humorless face. “If it’s change that you fear, just select Option 3!” She hisses. “There’s a queue waiting here, can’t those eyes of yours see?!”

You follow the black-nailed finger to its pointed destination; and sure enough, the jumbled jokester seems to be telling the truth. A host of fellow tourists stand there, varying in garb, walks of life, and sunburn levels, but all carry vague looks of impatience on their faces. The leaf-clad elf stands knock-kneed in front of all of them, apparently trying to assuage their frustration with a loredump as Jingle did, shooting nervous glances back at the selfsame jester ever so often.

You read the option she’s pointed: ‘Otherworldly Adventurer’. Unlike the premade options that sit above it or even the empty character sheet with its countless footnotes and asterisks, the option’s description is small enough to render it remarkably inconspicuous in comparison. It reads: ‘Boosted XP gain: No MeConstruction.’

“What’s a MeConstructi—?”

“Sign it!” growls Jingle, impatience evidently boiling over. The queue behind her jostles a bit more, their beleaguered guide waving her hands wildly to regain their attention. You meet the jester’s glare for a second… then check off the option, scrawling your John Hancock on the bottom of the page.

Sure, you may have consigned yourself to a maybe-eternity as some fantasy-pastiche stereotype, but the mirthful jester’s countenance looked downright murderous. Better a sorceress than a stain on the tarmac.

To your quick relief, no magenta-knockout-glitter is sprayed into your face, nor are you suddenly accosted by unusually muscular women. Your wrist is encircled by Jingle’s unusually strong hand, though, and you are dragged to the airport’s main exit, despite your best efforts to wriggle out.

A refrain of “OwfuckgoddamnSTOPPIT,” echo into the empty halls accompanied by, of course, the slight tinkle of bells.

~~~


You’re around two minutes from any human sighting — save your personal harlequin-tormentor — when you are finally released, Jingle choosing instead to slam your paper into the same book-cum-document-scanner as you lightly massage your tender wrist.

You examine your surprisingly austere surroundings — there’s no trace of any fantasy aesthetic save for a (comparative to the landing hall) small mural of a dragon on the otherwise bare blue concrete walls. A (faux, you think) wooden door with the labeling plaque ‘STABLES’ lies on the other end of the largeish rooms, red leather ropes hemming in a surprising dearth of tourists.

You give Jingle a wide berth as she impatiently fiddles with a velvet rucksack with the helpful moniker ‘BAG OF TRICKS’ sewn into its back. One half of you is urging that you get the hell away from this maniac and the other emphatically insists that you do not run, lest she turn you into a newt or something. You’re obeying the second urge right now — WonderWorld, as promised in its manifold adverts, has made a part of you believe in magic, but certainly not the good time

Jingle stops her rummaging and turns her attention to you, a sharp movement of her wrist propelling something your way. You overcome your coulrophobia long enough to obey the implicit order of ‘Catch’, enclosing the object in your hands.

It’s some kind of amalgam of a smart watch and a tablet, too big to be called the former and too small to be called the latter. The edges surrounding the black mirror of the center appear to be made of some kind of imitation brass, little bumps of fake rivets punched into it. All in all, it’s kinda steampunky, which isn’t exactly matching the aesthetic of the —

SNAP

You wince, and incline your gaze to the jester once more. One hand is raised in post finger-snap but quickly transitions to impatient gestures of strapping something to her wrist, marking the second occasion of her eschewing the annoying rhymes for mimery, which, in a way, was kinda wor—

SNAP-SNAP

You raise a hand to your ringing ears and frown at the Jester, who answers back with a sneer. “I liked it better when you talked,” you mumble, as you fasten the thing to your wrist.

The screen shines to life, a little plate-armored knight walking across the bottom in lieu of a loading bar. Little messages pop up: ‘Initializing Guest ‘Robert’, ‘Aligning Stats,’ ‘Injecting Status ConditiCard.’

A pinch in the base of your wrist accompanies the last notification, drawing a small squawk of pain from your lips. You fiddle with the buckle desperately, but the band seems to tighten, if anything. You brandish your hand at Jingle, hissing “What did you do?!”

She’s smiling once again, and shrugs casually. “It’s standard practice, dearest boy.” She resumes walking forwards, cavorting over the leather ropes with graceful pointe. “You’ll have much fun with your new toy.”

You grumble and follow her to the wooden stables door, still fiddling with the band of the computer. The knight has progressed through ¾ of the tablet-watch, his sword raised in a display of heroic valor. The stables continue the painfully artificial world of Wonder™ you’ve come to expect; each stray bit of faux-hay anchored to the floor; walls, pillars, and swinging doors each formed of wood-textured plastic; and a fleet of uncannily still horses lashed to chariots.

You suspect animatronics.

Jingle stands next to a particularly ornate carriage, a round bulb of white laced with white filligree, snow-coloured horses attached with ivory bridles that the small segment of your heart that is bleeding hopes against hope is artificial. A small tinkle accompanies each impatient foot-tap, smile stretched across her face now with a jagged and kind of strained edge to it.

“Well, my dear, here’s our ride!” A quick flourish and tap of her stave against the vehicle reveals a fairly comfy-looking compartment, lined with red velvet. “Now we’re off to meet your bride!”

“Th- I said that’s not what I wanted!!” you splutter.

“It’s what you wrote and what you’ll find, valued guest,” coos the jester. “A princess in mind, and also in chest!” Jingle cups two sumptuous handfuls of air in the front of her own flat uniform.

Again, this was a concerning-slash-extraordinarily-intriguing possibility. “Jesus, are you guys going to brainwash him?”

Jingle seems to be in her element as she pirouettes around your carriage, adding in a slight skip ever so often to keep things fresh. “His mind shan’t be washed, just given a rinse! You can be what you want, from offspring to prince!”

A wink accompanies the last statement, along with a deep bow and flourish directed at the carriage’s open door. You enter, dry-mouthed as potential scenarios whirl through your head, from potential revenge from all the cons you were dragged to and the girls scared off by fantasy-trivia; to how maybe, potentially, you could ask your bipolar guide if you could take the princess home.

What is of a very low concern is the how or if of turning him back.
1432214.title: Chose the third option.

choices: Power - you want to impress dad with your strength
Ardor -you may need to mental fortitude to restrain yourself around the Princess
14322141.content:
The red velvet cushions are comfortable enough, though there is the distinct smell of disinfectant within the bulbular carriage. They must rinse these things down after each use - they are ivory-and-gold coloured plastic vehicle was a wedding carriage after all. Artificial roses and lilies adorn the outside.

A number of guests use the park as romantic getaways, acting out sensual fantasies and whirlwind romances in the space of a week, culminating in a wedding. Some even use the opportunity to renew their vows, and it is said that the entire staff is legally ordained to conduct such ceremonies.

The satin drapes fall into place over the windows, placing the carriage into chlorinated shade, illuminated by the glow of the screen about your wrist. With just the slightest creak of rusty servos, the animatronic horses break into a canter, all at once, throwing you off balance. As you catch yourself with your hand, you notice the fingers of the arm strapped to the device are sluggish and numb. You rub some sensation into them. The digital knight, having finished his quest to the end of the loading bar, is now stripped of his armour, sweat beads emanating from his head as struggles to heft his pixelated broadsword in a repeating 2-frame animation.

-- synchronising guest--

The numb sensation is crawling up over your elbow. Above the knight, the interface cycles through a series of numbers.

Power: 7..... Finesse: 6..... Cognition: 11..... Ardor: 12..... Arcanum: 0..... Divinity: 0..... Luck: 1

Were these you? Your, or rather your character's, attributes? You've sat in on enough of your father's D&D games to make an educated stab at what the attributes mean. Power 7 could be referring to your physical strength, with 10 presumably the average. It's almost enough to raise your indignation but a testing flex of your scrawny, pubescent biceps quickly douses that fire. They're not wrong. You'll just have to be happy with Cognition 11.

Finesse must be a measure of nimbleness - somehow Wondertainment or the machine at least, must know how clumsy you are. Ardor - you surmise that must be charisma, passion, strength of will, that sort of thing.

You wonder if dad is being "statted" up right now too. There are probably technicians working behind the scenes to put his "character sheet" together. That will be the easy part. Making him match the character, the role of Princess Allaria, that will be enough job entirely. You refuse to believe it is possible. Not even sculpting his sagging middle-age flesh into that fey, feminine form, but getting him to play the part. Impossible.

Then again, you've seen him play female characters in his tabletop campaigns before. Sure, he had always approached the roles with an over-the-top high-pitched squark that wouldn't be out of place in a Monty Python sketch. Sure, his comprehension of womanhood was to hide behind the male characters. But Princess Allaria was a charicature of a distressed damsel - he may well do the role justice.

The carriage emerges from the stables onto a cobbled street. Pulling back the drape and glancing back, you watch as Jingle waves you away, before a puff of purple smoke at her feet almost conceals her tugging out a pack of cigarettes as she ducks into a side door.

The carriage bounces along between rows of wattle-and-daub buildings carefully built by architects to lean precipitously towards one another over the street, providing shade for the taverns, blacksmiths, guildhalls and such that line the streets. The carriage travels at quite a pace, the legs of the horses cantering at a blur, granting you only brief glimpses at the guests thronging the walkways. The predominantly colour is human pinks and browns, but you catch flashes of spiked, emerald humanoids; a red and gold woman whose robes undulate like flames; and a rather high number of figures walking around this supposedly family theme park in the nude.

The carriage brakes to a halt suddenly to allow a pedestrian to cross, giving you enough time to notice a young girl breaking away from her mother's hand to nervously tugging at the robes of a fearsome seven-foot giant, pointing at the nude figure at his side. The giant bears his tusks in a grin, tugging harshly at the silver chain in his hand that leads to the figure's collared neck. The figure - not nude but covered in a layer of short fur from head to toe - obediently lowers its head for the child to pet the catlike ears that sit atop them.

The mother of the young child doesn't even notice. She is otherwise distracted, locked in the passionate embrace of a slender, elven woman. The elf's hands explore the human guest's body, which goes unnoticed by the crowd. Such things must be commonplace.

In advertising, Wondertainment plays down the sexual aspects of their park. It is "for kids and adult kids". Yet put a bunch of people in their dream bodies, tell them to live out their wildest fantasies, and give them free reign to do as they please with the park's staff, and of course their baser impulses are going to rise to the surface.

What was it Jingles said? '“You’ll have much fun with your new toy.” Well, thank God you have 'Cognition 11' and 'Ardor 12'. Smarts enough to see through the phoniness of Wondertainment, and the mental strength to resist any temptation. So what if you have Princess Allaria to yourself for the entire vacation - there was no way you're going to forget who she really is on the inside, no way that you might lose your inhibitions for a moment, to sample her body, use her, plunge yourself between the velvet folds of her quivering, fey pu-

Ah, the burden of Cognition 11. With some relief, the numbness exuded by the watch has spread down over your midsection and groin. Dad can count on you to keep a cool head. Speaking of which, your jaw goes numb. Your head is getting fuzzy.

The watch bleeps.

-- One free advancement --
-- Please select --

It must want you to chose one of the stats to add to. It flicks between them, your finger hanging over the screen as you decide what to favour.
14322141.title: Looking — and being disappointed — at your ...

choices: … find yourself smack-dab in the middle of an invasion.
… get frogmarched to a wardrobe room, for a ‘fitting’.
143221414.content:
Your fuzzy head lolls on its numbing neck, as you consider the possibilities. Sure, you could put a few points in Power and bulk yourself up to bodybuilder-tier levels, but you’d hardly need that much to manhandle protect your slope-eared ward. Probably.

The not-unpleasant static in your body intensifies enough to buckle your spine, exhorting you to lie languidly down on the velvet cushions. The artificial scent of lemon disinfectant grows stronger as you approach the ground.

You lazily contemplate Finesse. You’d argue with the 6, but your brief stint with baseball in second-period gym would argue right back. You somehow managed to pitch the ball right over the backstop. Speccing into it seems a waste.

Luck seems an intriguing possibility. How would that manifest in the plastic-and-staff run WonderKingdom? Built in release-mechanisms in all noble elves’ dress? Foes tripping and breaking their necks before combat? Your finger hovers over it, but you decide otherwise. Starting you off with only one point seems an insult, and you don’t want to humor any staff that were possibly watching.

The other ones considered, you gravitate towards your 0-point options, Divinity and Arcanum. Both are interesting, if you’re looking at it from a character-building sense. Would more Divinity allow you to ask for a boon from a staff member playing at apotheosis? Could Arcanum let you conjure flames from nowhere, and conjure pretty light shows with a flick of the hand?

You vacillate between the two, finger slowly drooping from lethargy, until it lands down somewhere on the screen. A little boop confirms your choice, but your heavy eyelids are already falling, with your mind, into a deep sleep.

~~~


You wake up to a particularly jolt-y bump of the carriage that raised and dropped your head onto the soft velvet. The light filtering through the curtains has taken an ochre hue, and the fuzziness is altogether gone from your body.

You stretch the sleep from your limbs with a languid groan, your fingers brushing the corrugated metal of the carriage. You blink once. Then twice. A third for good measure. How long were you out? Did you lose a day?

You stand up unsteadily and lurch to the curtains, snicking them open as surreptitiously as you can. Stood in front of a plastic tree just a ways ahead is an elven woman, dressed in armor that would probably be useful in a fight, provided no one targeted her midriff, arms, the outer part of her thighs, or her collarbone. Her weight is lazily balanced against a spear tucked in the crook of her arm. One hand is brought up to her lips, the other fiddling with a lighter.

She watches you roll up with sullen irritation, before bringing one hand to her pointed ear while wincing, hiding the other behind her back. Her eyes widen in surprise and she snaps into a wobbly salute at your carriage, her smile rimmed with bloodshot eyes.

You pull the curtains back. You’re in elf-country now, you assume, judging by similar guards down the line standing in front of similar trees, though none quite as… distracted as that one.

You suspect that love of ‘pipeweed’ is not in elven lore.

You slouch back with a putter of the lips and stare up at the ceiling. Come to think of it, what is elven lore? From what you can cobble together from your bad memories of Dad’s beloved fantasy show, the answer would be ‘not much’. You think you saw precisely one elf in (the same vital-organ-baring) armor during that animated drudgery, and she might have been part of a background cel.

Most of the elvery you saw was dialogue-and-intrigue-centric, which probably was an animator’s trick to minimize budget or effort, the lazy clods. When the generic protagonist got into a fight — and he often did, the rapacious scamp — both hero and foes’ limbs jerked about like clockwork automatons. Still, Allaria’s animation was shockingly fluid, so the person who sketched the manifold rounded edges of the elf must’ve done so as a passion project.

Well, you’d doff your cap to whomever put pen to bosom — provided they weren’t on the streets, a cursory internet search revealed that the show was absolutely reamed by ratings boards after its first airing, incurring enough fines that any amount of horny cartoon-aficionados couldn’t save it.

So it was a long-burning torch that your dad held for the Princess, probably. And now — if the rhyming jester’s words were to be believed — he was her. Was that ironic? It felt ironic.

You turn your mind to thoughts about how you are definitely not excited for this. You then squeeze your knee as hard as you can to dispel your morning wood, which chose this purely coincidental time to show itself.

You’d both probably laugh about this in a while.

Your watch flashes. The pixelated knight has once again donned his armor and is facing the screen, pumping his sword holding arm up and down. The words ‘NEW QUEST’ flashes above him in golden gothic font.

You idly thumb it. A grey box expands as the knight unfolds his arms like a circus ringleader, accenting the rectangle with the point of his sword. ‘MEET THE PRINCESS’ heads the top of the box in the same gold-filigreed text.

The hammering of your heart becomes more pronounced, but a blinking ‘!’ notification takes the balance of your attention. You press it whilst trying not to frown out of impatience, but the urge disappears when the text ‘SELECT SPELL’ appears on the screen.

The wide grin across your face is filled with childlike wonder instead of lascivious anticipation for once. A small pseudo-benefit of dad’s insistent show-pushing was a fascination for the arcane arts, an interest that was thoroughly quashed by the stodgy first law of thermodynamics and a host of other disappointing realities.

Your 6 Finesse certainly didn’t help with any of the close-up magic tutorials you attempted, but it seems that your least favorite megacorp might lend a helping hand.

Deciding to blithely ignore all the frightful environmental and labor law violations for now, you eagerly tap the two words of promise…

...only to be greeted with a disappointingly brief 3-option list that provides, ‘Kindle’, ‘Create Water’, and ‘Chill Touch’ as your only three options.

You frown. What a gyp. Where were the Firebolts and the Power Words, the Raise Dead’s and Eldritch Blasts? Leave it to Wonderworld to corpora-sanitize magic. A few determined scroll reveal a larger list of tantalizingly greyed magicks, including ‘Charm Person’ and ‘Brew Potion’, though no stat requirement is listed next to them.

The descriptions bring similar disappointment. The most promising option ‘Kindle’ specifies the start of ‘small fires’ in ‘predetermined spots’, quashing any of your latent aspirations to pyromania; ‘Create Water’ is limited to two cups of water per hour; and Chill Touch, well, is Chill Touch.

You pick Create Water with the hardest consternated tap you can muster. Maybe if you’re thirsty, you can slake your thirst, though you doubt a vacation resort would try to starve out its guests. The screen flashes with instructions: Apparently all you have to do is bend your right hand’s fingers like so…

A mist of what you dearly hope is water sprays from an invisible port on your tablet as if from a motor-powered spritzer, which is probably what it is, judging by the buzz from your tablet..

You unclench your fingers after five seconds of power-rapt staring, but it’s enough to leave all of your velvet cushions soaking wet.

The rest of your ten-minute carriage ride is spent standing, balefully staring at the wet pillows. You’re thankful that the carriage door automatically opens, having some elvish guard hide their giggles at your sodden seats would be too much to bear.

You take a step out into what is presumably the fey kingdom of Tyr — with more than one glower at its soaked interior — and…
143221414.title: Arcanum!

choices: ...  trying to beat the everloving -shit- out of you.
... chewing you out, while paradoxically hanging on your every word.
... cooing compliments and praise your way with hate in her eyes.
1432214141.content:
You descend upon a small green patch of astroturf, struggling to keep balance on the plastic made slick by your sodden soles. Internally — and begrudgingly — you admit that the sight is… somewhat impressive. The architectural style of Tyr seems to be some kind of Roman-and-art-deco pastiche, with smooth huts made out of faux-marble with tall pillars lining the dusty paths somewhat haphazardly.

A large archway seems to be grown into the tree’s base, and you can catch glimpses of an ornate hall beh— you catch yourself before you engage in unabashed admiration of your hated, company foe.

Everything is fake. Everything was probably made on the backs of unpaid workers, and used by the debaucherous elite to engage in their basal urges; you just happen to be caught up in the teeth of its grinding, corporate gears. You mustn't enjoy yourself.

Your half-stagger towards a nearby foodstand run by a perky, spike-eared youth is simply to grease the wheels of rebellion, nothing more.

The ‘younger’ elves are more your speed. Bright, bubbly, and filled with some kind of naive curiosity towards ‘mayflies’ — the somewhat insulting nickname given to the mortal races. The food vendor you chatted up wasn’t actually fifty, you were pretty sure, she certainly was experienced in acting, with the way she cooed and her put a sparkle in her bright eyes as you stammered an (error-ridden) explanation of how waterwheels worked.

You’ve been sat on a grassy knoll for a bit, finishing off your food’s wrapping — the leaf was made of fondant! — when you remember the pressing issue you must address. Prodding a sticky finger into your tablet computer, you bring up the ‘MEET THE PRINCESS’ quest. Frustratingly, no flavor text accompanies, though a ‘TRACK QUEST’ button is nestled neatly in the corner.

You stab it, expecting some costumed actor to appear out of a nearby trapdoor… not the brief but intense migraine that accompanies the bloop. After the few seconds of pain, you open your eyes to a small illuminated line on the ground.

It shimmers and waves as you stare at it, like a mirage or luminescent floater, but you can see, out of the corner of your eye, the path leading into the large plaster tree on the horizon. You follow the path at a crooked gait, trying to balance not looking directly at the image with actually following it, all the while considering that this is a massive violation of your body, an event that you specifically wanted to avoid —

When a shrill, feminine scream echoes from the tree’s arched halls.

Your heart hammers. A sound that high, and that wheedling… it can only be the Princess. You summon every last bit of your 12 Ardor to proceed forward bravely, despite your lack of any means to thwart any kidnapping attempt. What could you do with a measly 7 Power and two cups of water?

You stride forward nonetheless. Your 11 Cognition will find you a way out of this, somehow.

Crouched over in a half-skulk, you sneak to the first step… only for the wind to be, quite quickly and completely, taken out of your sails.

On top of a steep, velvet-lined staircase a tall, flaxen-haired figure in elaborate, gold-lined clothes is dabbing at the face of a shorter, but much more eye-catching figure with a handkerchief. The diminutive one is squirming in an attempt to escape the shoulder-grip of her taller captor, pointy ears flattened against her head — all the while hurling out squeaky curses that you’re one-hundred percent sure aren’t Wondertainment-friendly — but to no avail, either her captor is too strong, or she’s simply too weak.

Your breath hitches in your chest for a second, and the taller one takes notice of the noise, ceasing her unwanted ministrations and drawing the shorter one’s attention towards you with a gentle wave.

The taller, androgynous figure gently plucks a golden circlet off of the other’s head, placing it gently on a nearby velvet pillow, but she doesn’t seem to notice her new lack of headgear. She doesn’t seem to notice much else besides you, and you’re reciprocating her rapt attention.

The holographic line is swirling around her feet, but you don’t need it to know who she is. You’ve seen her in glimpses of old taped episodes and on the plane: Princess Allaria, in the flesh.

The rounded, smooth, bared-in-manifold-places, flesh.

You moisten your dry lips with your tongue. Shit. Did you brush your teeth before getting on the plane? Put your deodorant on? Maybe she caught you staring at her tits, fuck. Dad always said—

And then the thing that you definitely should have remembered hits you. If mischievous WonderWorldian jesters were to be believed, that was your dad mincing towards you. You squint at her cherubic face. Is there makeup? A mask?

A terrifying prospect crosses your mind. Could the same holographic-pathmaker put an alluring fey veil over your paunchy dad? Is that damned perpetually-smirking elf up there simply watching the most awkward family reunion, with dad’s hairy belly poking out of his lace-and-taffeta costume?

right at you.

The princess tumbles off you with a squawk as you stare at your hand. Your mind is awash with relief and the roaring jubilance of a grand achievement. The former because that definitely wasn’t your dad's holograph-swaddled chest your hand came across — something in your lizard brain says that it was pure, unvarnished boob you just honked.

"My humblest apologies, Sir Knight. It seems when I am around you I... I cannot control myself." A crimson blush flushes into existence on her cheeks in a second. "The winds of Fate doth guide my actions and my words. Tellst me, master, is this how thy wished to have me? Aren't thou not happy with thy work?"

Seraphina runs through the corridors of the castle, down spiralling staircases, tugging you along behind her. Her skirt is demurely hiked up to allow her legs to sprint, and you can't help but admire the skill with which she navigates the twists and turns in those heels without breaking an ankle. Arriving at an intersection, she pivots balletically on a heel as she takes a hard right.

She wasn't even out of breath, nor sweating (although you doubt if Wondertainment-brand princesses ever sweat). Dad would have been bent double and gasping by now. Either they seriously boosted his cardio when they did... whatever it is they did, or it is just the removal of half of his body weight that has really taken a load off.

"How do you know where you're going?"

"I can hear them!" she cries back giddily. She hops and skips down another flight of stairs to a lower floor, dances past an elven scullery maid, and turns a corner into the stables. Screeching to a surprise halt with a gasp of delight, you bump hard into the back of her, only the shock-absorbing properties of the bustle and her luscious backside stopping her from being propelled forward into the mounds of fresh hay.

Two dozen horses stand to attention within their stalls along each wall. Halfway down the stable, you catch sight of a slim elven girl jumping up from a bail of hay. She seeks around for anywhere to stash the immersion-breaking smartphone she was just playing on, settles on quickly stuffing it down her cleavage, before grabbing a horse brush from the wall and darting into one of the stalls. You catch sight of her peeking nervously over the top of one of the horses at the two of you.

Seraphina hasn't noticed. She is standing ramrod straight, her eyes closed in an expression of rapture and her hands held either side of her head as if she's Professor Xavier. "So many voices... I can hear them all!" she cries in delight. She dashes to the closest horse, throwing her slender arms about its neck and resting her head against its fur. "This one... his name is... Heartblossom..." She plants a gentle kiss on his snout. "I hear you, Heartblossom."

In that moment, she looks the very image of a Wonder™ Princess. Oh God, if she's going to start singing about Colours of the Wind or Circles of Life, I'm out. She moves to the next horse along, eagerly naming that one Silverlight, stroking her hands over its fine grey coat.

You wonder what part of her is in control right now. There is little of the inner turmoil evident in this moment - perhaps dad's love of medieval fantasy roleplay and whatever force puppeteers her have found a common ground. She seems genuinely delighted to be imagining herself able to hear the voices or thoughts of these beasts.

If beasts they are...

This place looks like a stable. But it doesn't smell like one. Sure, it has the smell of fresh hay, yet what stable ever smells fresh? The golden hay piled high about your feet doesn't show the slightest touch of manure, and the air lacks a certain horsey tang of sweat and animal urine.

While the horses look real - no visible metal joints at least - it occurs to you that none of the stalls are closed, and the horses are completely untethered, but they don't run. They could be medicated, of course. They could be animatronics. Or they could be controlled by the same guiding force that has dad under its spell. Certainly if they can control a man to talk and act in such a way, making an animal stand to attention must be child's play. As you watch Seraphina continue to frollick about the horses, a disquieted shudder runs down your spine at the thought of the power wielded by this corporation. The power to control bodies and minds, power never meant for mortal men, let alone money-grubbing corporate executives.

Something has to be done about this. When you're back at school, you swear to make your next presentation a scathing diatribe about this holiday. You wonder if they'll let you use dad as show-and-tell... You're sure your male friends would like that...

You're not taking him home, let's nip that one in the bud right now. Can you imagine getting him past passport control looking like this? Or what your mom would say if he came back in feminine frocks and frills. This is only temporary, and in just a few days he'll be back to his normal, flabby, middle-aged self, and you'll both be left to deal with the horrible, awkward fallout of it all.

-so might as well make the most of it while you can-

Directing your curiosity back to the horses, you step closer to the nearest - Heartblossom she'd called it. It doesn't react to your presence beyonf a small turn of the head. Running your fingers through the coat, the fur certainly feels real. The muscle underneath is suitable flesh-y. If it is indeed animatronic, it is at least real horse hide stretched over a metal skeleton.

The only thing of note is a small plastic stud hidden behind one ear. Squinting closer, in tiny letters there is a name - Heartblossom.

"Huh. I'll be danged. Maybe she can speak to the animals," you ponder aloud. Or she has the knowledge of the animal's names burned into her brain, the same way she seems to know the layout of the castle or how to walk in heels. There is perhaps one way to find out.

You grab the horses' ear and give it a sharp tug.

"Hey!" Seraphina marches towards you, a displeased sulk on her face. She draws herself up to her lackluster height and jabs you in the center of the chest with an accusatory finger. "You bully!"

"Me?" you ask innocent, overtly delighted at this adorable display of intimidation. "What I do?"

"Yon gentle steed says you nearly pulled his ear off!" She moved to soothe the horse with strokes and sweet words, while you can just gawp.

The pillar in question is one of five made of stone-patterned concrete, etched with "ancient" cracks and vines, that rise up through the center of the great tree. Swirling symbols glow dimly from within, flowing up in a steady stream from the base of the pillars to the ceiling, where the stone-patterned concrete meets the wood-patterned concrete of the tree. "It's, uh, really neat."

The Princess is staring up at the Pillar with rapt reverence on her face but as the spiel ends, she turns her gaze sharply to you. "Mayhaps if thou had paid more attention to thine lore, I wouldst not be in this situation?"

"And maybe if you hadn't left me with a bloody dancing goon to go have a piss for fifteen minutes, I wouldn't have had to be the one making the decision."

"Thou hardly appear dismayed about, my lord," she croons sweetly.

"Aggressive? Me? I wouldst never raise a sword, hero," she gasps in faux outrage.

"I said passive aggressive. Don't tell me Allaria doesn't know what passive means." Perhaps another stroke of her ear would remind her. "You keep making all these snide, glib remarks like you think I won't notice. God, you haven't changed at all, have you?" you snap, years of repressed frustration springing out. You're aware of the absurdity of the last remark as you speak it to a 46-year old man poured into the shape of a nubile fey maiden. "Yeah, I know you're pissed off. But I also know you can't say that to me directly. So why don't you just get over it, or I'll just start ignoring all the undertones of what you say, and just focus on the overtones, Seraphina."

Judging by the eyes, she doesn't like that at all. The thought of you willfully ignoring the soul silently screaming from within to treat her as the two-dimensional behavioural programming she finds herself trapped in must fill her with terror. With a deep inhalation, you add, "look, I'm sorry, okay?"

She musters the cutest little pout you've ever seen. "Tis easy to be gallant, when thou art the victor."

"All I'm saying is, let's just let bygones be bygones. And speaking of bygones," you segway seamlessly. "-tell me more about this pillar."

For the time being at least, that settles things. It isn't entirely clear if it is dad or Princess Seraphina exuberantly launching into a description of the history of the Pillars of Pen-hadar. Needless to say, he has been trying to tell you this lore for years, but she is far more easier on the ear and the eye. While you think he is the one with the knowledge, her actions are more suspect - her small hand slips into yours as she guides you from pillar to pillar, her free hand gliding over several of the shifting symbols as she describes their meaning. To both of your delights, her Elvish is quite fluent.

At great length, you are taught of the carving of the Pillars ten thousand years ago by the great hero Pen-hadar from the stone of Mount Tal-sharada during the Age of Winterdeep, when the entire world was covered in ice. With his tremendous strength, the hero had driven the pillars deep into the molten core of the planet, filling the world with warmth and new life. Each year, at the winter solstice, the enchantments that maintained the pillars had to be renewed through a ceremony or else spring would never come.

It was deeper lore than the cartoon had ever implied. Perhaps added in the expanded universe novel and comic that had come after, although you'd heard Wondertainment had stricken all those from canon recently in preparation for creating their own sequel. "Huh. I never knew the elves were so fleshed out."

"Oh, you'll find I'm quite fleshed out, hero," Princess Allaria purrs, intertwining her arm further with yours so that your upper arm is pressed against her delectably soft breast.

"Um... so this ceremony- what does that consist of?"

She lowers her gaze coyly and blushes deeply. "Tis a ceremony to bring new life to a dying world -how else does one create new life?" She gestures around at the circle of pillars, the center of which you now stand. "The pillars are the masculine - hard, potent, unyielding, rising up to penetrate the feminine - the Great Mother Tree, Womb of the World, bringer of life. Through their coupling, life is renewed." She twists to face you, such that your arm is now fully encased between her two succulent breasts. She inclines her head towards the stone at your feet, where a slight divot a centimetre deep and about the length of a person has seemingly been worn, as if be great age and use. "The Ceremony is a simple affair. One man. The pillar. One woman. The vessel. As the man fills the vessel with new life, so do the Pillars unto the world."

You can barely focus on her words, lost as you are in those beautiful, blue, angry eyes.

info.description:
Setting created by grumbus }

The innocuous name ‘Wondertainment’ belies a savagely litigious corporation dead set on dominating every media market they can. Owned and operated by the eccentric but brilliant Walter Wonder, the company has as many business ventures as it has outstanding lawsuits.

In an odd move around eight-or-so years ago, Walter (or Dr. Wonder, as he likes to be known) purchased the pharmaceutical company Meconstruction, a contender in the growing industry of automated plastic surgery. Investors and the public were puzzled at the new move, some postulating that they were pivoting away from entertainment altogether.

Mostly though, it was forgotten and dismissed as one of Walter’s insane pet projects. It was a massive surprise to all parties when the 23rd annual Wondercon was not centered around movie-promotion, but the opening of WonderWorld; ‘The Theme Park of the Future, Today!’

The park boasted a variety of environments to immerse their guests in:
Wonder-City, a sprawling metropolis populated by a plethora of caped heroes and spandex-clad villains;
Wonder-Kingdom, a medieval land of sword and sorcery, its forests populated with mysterious elves, and rocky plains inhabited by savage monsters;
Wonder-Academy, a venture into the vast amounts of intellectual property purchased from Japan, where improbably-colored hairstyles are the norm and the genre can change at the drop of a hat.

(Other boroughs are pending, of course.)

The roar of mouth-frothing fans drowned out the announcement of the extraordinarily exorbitant pricetag.

Included in the base package are three days in the Wonder-Place of your choice and a free body-resculpting to match the locals. Additionally, you are given a basic ‘Plotline’ to follow; a recently recruited hero for Wonder-City, a new adventurer for Wonder-Kingdom, a transfer student for Wonder-Academy, etc. etc. Packages have to be upgraded if you want to inhabit the role of an established character.

Any hanky-panky above PG-13 or violence beyond mild-roughhousing is strictly prohibited from both staff and guests — though one can bypass the former through underground channels. The actors in the park are well-trained, however, and can easily fake a dramatic death or budding romance at the drop of the hat.

As with anything owned by Wondertainment, the cheery facade masks a dark underbelly. The staff, by necessity, has been organized into a strict hierarchy; with management at the top; technicians, writers, and actors a rung lower on the ladder; and sanitation, maintenance, and grunt workers at the bottom. Bright eyes dazzled by the magical prospects touted by employment ads and the roaring river of Wonder-media usually leave the park glassy and disillusioned.

Actors are the most sought-after positions; for both the prestige of such a position and the benefits afterward. Contracts are set for five years at the minimum, and anyone who makes it through that crucible can get any Wondertainment-owned role they desire. The selection and training process is rigorous too, a strict regimen of lessons to teach them how to stay in-character no matter their form or situation.

Many a proud graduate of that program have been bitterly disappointed by the nature of their assignment. Gender, age, height: all these and more are no barrier to the Wondrous™ auto-surgeons of Meconstruction!

(Rumors swapped amongst the maintenance staff suggest that willingness is equally dismissable, as exemplified by the impetuous thespians who left their ‘disciplinary sessions’ as legendary method actors.)

Writers are assigned to create exciting new Plotlines for their awaiting guests. There are a few that create Wonderful™ experiences every time they put pen to paper, but a fair amount of the writer’s room is burnt out, and just rehash usual tropes for their none-the-wiser guests. A few luminaries are employed as coaches for the actors, watching plots unfold through contact-lens cameras whilst whispering plot twists and story directions into the actor’s cleverly hidden earpieces. Whether the actors listen or not is a bit of a toss-up.

Technicians are stretched to their creative limit as well by Wondertainment’s nigh-unmeetable quota: designing new animatronics for creatures and roles unoccupiable by humans; new gadgets to enhance the realism of each environment; and pushing the envelope of Meconstruction’s technology.

(There are rumblings of discontent among the actors about artificially intelligent robots created to take their starring roles in the park, but those are mostly dismissed with much rolling of the eyes and scoffs of ‘Science fiction!’)

Wonder-World’s mantra is ‘customer-obsession’, after all. Who needs to follow labor laws when you have mountains of cash?
